(From notes). Undated 12 ounce bottle served in pint glass. Appreciate the serving instructions on the label. 

Appearance: Pours with a hazy, light orange-gold body and a towering airy bone head ... so much head, I could not get the entire bottle in my pint glass without waiting and drinking. Robust carbonation is also evident in the beer itself. Settling of the head is slow (at least for someone waiting to taste this beer) and leaves blotches of sticky lace on the sides.

Smell: Citrusy hops hit first, from a little distance. Closer sniffing reveals spicy and floral notes, and hints of lightly baked sour dough bread. Nice complex mix of aromas. 

Taste: Nice mix of hops, malt yeast and other flavors. Not as yeasty or spicy as some "Belgian style" brews. {This is good thing}. Hints of lemon, generic citrus, pepper, and orange peel. Excellent sweet/bitter balance with little sourness. I also liked the malt/hop balance. Clean and brisk -- not terms that usually come to mind for Belgian style beers. 

Mouthfeel: Medium body. High carbonation is soft, and more obvious by sight than on the tongue. Semi-dry finish. 

Overall: A fine Belgianesque beer with enough hops to make a real difference in flavor and bitterness. Nicely avoids over spicing, but is a little bit over-carbonated.

Des parfums de coriandre et de pâte à pain dans lesquelles poussent des notes fruitées très intéressantes.  Des saveurs appréciables.  Des oranges.  Des épices belges.  Du poivre blanc.  Des herbes légèrement grasses.  Une sensation houblonnée assez agréable.  En bouche, un corps de moyenne densité avec un bon pétillement et une texture crémeuse.  Une finale modérément sèche avec des houblons parfumés et des épices bien senties.  Cette bière est bien adorable avec ses capacités houblonnées et son caractère épicé.  En fait, il est bien difficile de ne pas reconnaître que cette offrande est très facile à boire, savoureuse et pleine de bonne volonté.

Pours cloudy dark straw with a large foam off white head. Looks like a wheat beer.  Aroma is wheat and yeast. Bitter. Smooth start of gentle floral hops, sweet into bitter wheatish hops. Good and so smooth.
Has a good flavor just extremely hoppy. Hops is a little overpowering for my tastes. Just a 1 time try if you dont like beer that has a hoppy taste then dont try.
Pours light amber gold with a yeasty funky nose. Long lasting lace. Good amount of sweet malts and tropical fruit flavours balanced with very american flavoured hops.

Pours a cloudy orange with a thick frothy head. Aroma reveals bright citrus dominated by oranges. Taste is crisp and sharp citrus with a bitter and clean finish. A touch of sour notes due to citrus. Also a touch of caramel from the malt.

Bottle. Pours a golden copper with huge off-white head. Aroma is slightly fruity with a strong scent of Belgian yeast. Taste is herbal flavors, sweet malt, and rich yeast. Not bad.

Presentation: 12 oz. brown bottle with bottling date and "best by" date printed on the neck. Served in an oversized wine glass.

Appearance: Deep, gold color with a slight orange tint. White 2 finger head that dies out rather quickly. Lacing is not that great.

Smell: Its an herbal, musky smell. With a distinct malt sweetness plus a yeast hint.

Taste: Very full and herbal flavor that balances out really well with the sweetness from the malt and the perfect hop bitterness note. 

Mouthfeel: Feels dry and doesnt have that much carbonation. It goes down smooth, and is fairly drinkable.

Overall: Refreshing and easy to drink. It has just enough complexity to be interesting but not overwhelming. A very nice American attempt that stacks up nicely against the Belgians. It doesnt quite trump them, but its still a great brew.

Poured for a bottle into a tulip glass, Strog head with excellent retention. Pale orange in color. Stiff foamy peaks. Slight fruity aroma, not overpowering though. Pleasant enough tasting. Somewhat typical for a pale ale. Mout hfeel is a little too rough for my taste. very pleasant finish though. A very good beer but wouldnt be my first choice to have again.

On tap at Dexters, pours a murky orange with a thin head, not pretty by any means at all, aroma has a little bit of fruit and citrus but the yeast comes through as well, the flavor has yeast forward front end with a little but if fruit in the finish, kind of a dry finish, not bad.
Golden white head. Citrus and floral aroma. Taste is fruity and crisp. Very refreshing.
It poured a golden color with a small white head. The aroma was of grapefruit, hay, pepper and some lemon. The taste was fairly bitter, with a decent sweetness. Not bad.
Delicious, first rating so bear with me. Poured hazy and gold, thick white head. Medium hoppiness. Went down great, and an awesome aftertaste.

This beer is very drinkable. Good session beer. Citrus notes come through and it has that yeasty/earthy finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Poured draught at local Belgian bar. A nice Belgian pale ale with alot of hoppiness and citrus notes.
I really like the aftertaste and palate created with whatever yeast this one uses.

Reviewed 1/5/2013. Portion of a 750mL bottle poured into a pint glass.

A: Pours a semi-hazy golden color with intense looking carbonation. The head is a four finger offwhite shade. Decent retention, but nice texturing and plenty of patchy lacing.

S: The hops give it a strong herbal, piny, and grassy aroma. All of this melds with the cloves, bubblegum, apple, and ripe pear the Belgian yeast gives off. Not sure of its age, but the aromatic qualities still come together nicely - if a bit too bitterly.

T: Seemingly far more balanced in the flavor than the aroma. Initially, theres a lightly grassy and peppery flavor, before it permutes into a grapefruit sensation on the finish. Theres a touch of toffee (not caramel, though) somewhere in the midtaste. Complex enough (and I do mean enough. No need to ruin this with a haphazard profile) and incredibly refreshing.

M: This one comes across lighter than it may seem, due to the way the finish dries out the yeast and the slight sweetness. Not as carbonated as it initially appeared. Enjoyably crisp.

O: What puts this beyond the average summertime beer is its ability to transport its drinker from cold, dreary doldrums to a grassy field during a warm summers day in Upstate NY. Okay, that was really damn corny, but this beer is THAT refreshing. It makes me wish it wasnt 35 degrees out, thats for sure.

Pretty mediocre outing from Brewery Ommegang. Belgian Pale Ales are a favorite and this hit the right marks, just not memorably. Bright hoppiness, tight white head, light fruity sourness leads to a crisp,clean finish.

12oz bottle. Pours hazy gold with a big pillow of white head that laves heavy lacing. Spicy, citrusy, yeasty lemon aroma. Taste is the same with a nice fresh, grassy hops bittnerness that really lingers. Very crisp and refreshing.
Poured a hazy golden color with a huge foamy white head, nose is of plenty of citrus and hops and perhaps floral too.  flavor includes malts, hops and yeast. Very well crafted beer, quite enjoyable.

Pours a hazy golden colour with big white sticky head lacing lace all up the glass. Aromas of biscuits, fruity(orange and pear), toasted malts some yeast and sorta spicy. Flavours are citrus, spicy, toast, buiscuts, nutty, mild bitterness, and a nice soft sweetness.

Pours a cloudy orangish copper with a frothy white head that leav s panty of lacing. Aroma of fruity esthers, yeast and floral notes. Taste is yeasty with some fruits and some earthy hops. Great balance of hops with a nice bitterness on the finish, excellent bpa.

Draft at Taps 25, Lansing. Translucent medium straw-orange body, thick puffy off-white head. Sourish nose with freshly cut grass, lemon, and some clove. Grassy, leafy body, estery, with floral hops and an almost biting acidity. Delicate and rich. Another well-crafted classic from Ommegang.

Pours a finespun hazy gold with refined foam and good retention.  The nose is sour lemon with a little funk way in back.  Soft creamy head. Banana, soft fruits, spice, toffee malt.  Sparkling taste, very dry with medium carbonation.  Its a little heavier than it looks.  The alcohol is not perfectly hidden but darn awful close!  Its a pale ale so the sour bite from the hops is just good punctuation.  In an oversized wine glass this ale has graceful poise.
This brew was very well hopped, and it had an almost citrus flavor. Very enjoyable, says it is Seasonal, hope I can find some more to stock up.
Pours cloudy golden color with thick white foamy head.  Citrus aroma with cloves.   Sweet caramel start with yeasty clove flavors and citrus finish.
Pours a cloudy golden with significant head.  Strong hoppy flavor balanced well with floral undertones.  Crisp, dry finish.  Would definitely drink again.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a head of all foam finely sized white colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a and a fair lacing. The aroma was citrus and musty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The thick flavor contained notes of mild hops and malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.
Pours a cloudy copper color with lots of suspended yeast particles and big off white head.  Aroma is floral, spicy and malty.  Taste is citrus and sweet at the start with a hoppy finish.

Yessss, the 500th rating for this beer!  Bottle.  Nose drenched with juicy tropical fruit and lighter PNW traditionals ,bitter rind, some alcohol to burn the eyes.  Hazy orange body with a rocky beige head.  Taste alternates between dry and sweet, depending on whether the strong Belgian/Duvel yeast or the trop-hops are engaged.  Low bitterness but still leads the flavor race in the absence of any competitors.  Crisp and soft body and good head character all B-yeast with faint fruit and minerals.  Among the American copies, this is about as good as it gets.

Golden pour with a decent tight knit head. Belgian yeast in the nose with a hint of rye and aromatic hops. Lightly bitter on the tongue.   Middle is medium bodied, with malted grains and balanced hops. Hops ride the finish out.

Smells like a saison. Heavy on the yeast. Pours blond with pretty good lacing. Tastes pretty fruity. Has a good dose of alcohol. Some malt and citrus aroma as well. One of the better Ommegangs Ive had. A little touch of brett as well, just enough to make it interesting. On tap at Blue Monk.

Massive head and took 5 min just to pour a 12 oz. Golden orange in color. Smells like honey, citrus, bit of banana and yeasty funk. Flavor has more banana. Sweet and velvety mouthfeel for the style. Carbonation somehow comes in flat. Decent beer.

Nice mix of flavors. Strong Begian yeast aroma with some hoppiness. Nice dense golden color with a good two-finger head, somewhat foamy. Full carbonated palate. A little gassy. Well rounded flavor of yeast and malt but with a hint of citrus you might find in a Witbier. Nice hoppy top layer.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark golden color with a ridiculously thick head. Nose is a little sweet and fruity. Taste is a little sweet with some heavy fruit flavors in it.

Long Island, NY - 750 mL bottle poured a hazy dark amber color with good head, not much lacing. Good floral notes with some citrus. Taste is slightly citrus with nice IBU bite and malt backbone. Good overall pale ale.

Tart, yet medium bodied. Carbonation, almost sour-like, but the Belgian quality is still there.
On Draft. Nice amount tartness, hop, spice and bread. The finish was a bit pine and citrus. I like it.

Earthy citrus aroma, also pear, peach and grass. Golden orange color, some lacy, fine white head. Sweet fruit flavor contrasts with sharp bitter hops. I wouldnt call it a transition; these flavors appear together throughout. Light, effervescent body, pleasantly dry finish. Style hybrid that would be more surprising from a non-Belgian specific brewey.

On tap at the brewery as part of a tour,tasting and dinner. I love hop forward and Belgian beers some when you get both what more could you ask for. Aroma yeast,hops,citrus and lite fruityness. If you are in to hops or not you may still like it is not as bitter at the end like most of the hoppy beers I love but still full of flavor.

750 ml bottle.  Of course, after I buy this I see the very small best by 1/2011 on the top. Screwed again by bottles past their prime still on the shelf!  So the pour is a dark gold color with a thick head that leaves some nice lacing.  The aroma has grain, husk, cereal, caramel, and resin.  Bready and caramel flavors with plenty of yeasty notes, a little citrus, and slightly dry in the finish.  This is actually pretty decent.  Its a shame this isnt fresher. Added points for aging well though.

Pours a hazy brownish gold with a thick long lasting white head. Nose is non-descript. Palate is kmedium body with an upfront malt and hops at the end and aftertaste. Poured in a BPA glass from a 12 oz bottle. A good example of the genre. Enjoy!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a tullip glass. Pours a nice cloudy orange color with a white head that lasts a decent while and leaves great lacing. Aroma is very yeasty/grainy with a nice spicy phenol undertone. Flavor is a moderate sweet bitterness with undertones of citrus/floral that lasts a decent while. Mouthfeel is moderate/heavy carbonation overall that is dry/crips. I really like this beer.

Im going to do it... here we go... 4.8!
Exactly what I want in a beer. I never thought Belgian yeasts and NW hops could be blended correctly, and this made me very sad. This beer completely changed my outlook on this, and the brewers somehow used Cascadian hops to enhance the flavour. I dont know how they did it, but Ive been learning how to homebrew recently and can think of no other beer which I want to emulate more than this. Its quite expensive here in Canada but Im planning to buy many more.Love the balance between aroma and flavour so much, how they are at once completely new and unexpected, with the citrus hops on the nose and slight Belgian fruitiness on the tongue, yet go together so well.w00t

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, best before 4/25/2012.  Pours very cloudy golden orange color with a nice 2-3 finger fluffy off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice frothy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big pear, apple, lemon, pepper, grass, hay, earth, bread, herbal, and yeast spiciness.  Very nice aromas with good balance, strength, and complexity.  Taste of lemon, pear, pepper, grass, orange zest, apple, hay, earth, clove, herbal, bread, and yeast spices.  Lingering notes of light fruits, citrus, grass, herbal, earth, pepper, clove, bread, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice complexity and balance of flavors; no cloying flavors at all after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a lightly slick and crisp mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent Belgian pale ale!  Very well balanced with nice complexity; very smooth and crisp to drink.  Really enjoyed this, will be on the lookout for some fresher bottles for sure.

June 8th, 2010 - Ommegangs version of the Belgian Pale Ale is a wonderful, Proustian trip back to old vacations to Europe, ambling around museums and buildings that are generally much older than my country of origin. In particular, the smell reminds me of the aroma of the Louvre - a blend of aging wood, plaster, treated air, and somewhat dressed up tourists. On the edible end of the aroma spectrum I detect banana, nutmeg, black pepper and even some sweet potato - a strange assembly, but enough to cause hunger pangs. The flavor, like the aroma of the sweet potato, is both sweet and savory. Its deep and earthy and caramel sweetness, with a halo of marshmallow sweetness, though subtle and muted. The flavor is calm, served on a placid palate, and struggles to get the attention of my tastebuds, but while the volume might be a little low, Im loving the music.

Bottled.  Pours a cloudy pale gold.  Pillowy white head with impressive retention.  Light, slightly sharp, aroma of banana and orange peel, with some nice floral notes.  Lots of piney hops up front with tang of fruit mixed in with spicy notes of clove.  Finish is dry, with strong hop resin characteristics.  Watery mouthfeel, light-bodied.  A crisp, flavorful pale ale.
Draft at winners circle. Pours clear copper with a small white head. Aroma is typical white ipa with a tad more asringency. Taste is crisp, and dry, and lightly bitter.

Draft to pint (from notes).  I bought a 1/6 barrel of this for my kegerator. I should preface this review by saying that I was compromising with my wife on something because I wanted her to enjoy it too, as I usually like hop-heavy brews. And she loves it. Its good to me; just not distinctly memorable (although I remember every barrel I try in my kegerator). That being said, its smooth, like a Belgian Sierra Nevada, so its drinkability is excellent.
Cloudy gold,beige head.Nose is spicy & sweet malt.Tart fore,fruity mid, spicy hop finish. Medium alcohol heat.
Great citrus hops aroma , orange pour with a large of white head , great Belgian style beer
Multiple bottles.  Yellow pour with a white head.  Yeasty, citrusy aroma without many hops.  Lively carbonation and smooth easy to drink.  Pretty good beer.  Reminds me of hennepin.

Tap @ the Inaugural Boulder IPA Fest. Hazy, light orange appearance with an off white head. Spicy yeasty, orange citrusy, sweet aroma. Tangy orange citrusy, chewy yeasty, light bready, blood orange flavor. Pretty tasty.

Tap. Pours clear golden with a small creamy head and very nice lacing. Aroma is honey, caramel, grapefruit and a bit of yeast. Flavor is lightly tart and bitter with caramel/honey notes as well as lemon peel. Bitter finish, but more of a lemon peel bitter than a hoppy bitter. Looks beautiful, smells nice, downhill from there.

In bottle at Craigs. Pours a dark golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of pine, pineapple, caramel and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and CO2 prickle with a foamy mouth-feel. Mildly bitter with a dry finish.
bottle at home ... golden amber .. thin white head ... soft orange peach nose ... light bitter hop ... pine and orange ... soft yeast ... light saltyness ... bitter linger

slight citrus hops and Belgian yeast aroma... Clear yellow gold... Flavor is light an citrusy with notes of spices and Belgian yeast, yet incredibly crisp and light bodied... Very drinkable, impressive
12 oz Bottle pours hazy golden with a white head.  Aroma of yeast, spice, and malts.  Taste is the yeast, malt, sweet and a hint of spice.

From a tulip glass: Beautiful traffic-light yellow with a fragile puffy head. Yeast floating in the amber, which might be a turn off to some, but its just right for me. Got my tongue slapping me in the forehead in anticipation.

The aroma has the horseblanket of a Belgian blonde, but with the citrus hop of a West Coast IPA. There is a touch of funk, but it vascillates between this and a tangerine/grapefruit hop with each sniff. The aroma really takes a few extra minutes of attention.

The taste is slightly sour, or at least it hits the sour part of the tongue. The sourness comes from the yeast, which really tests the limits. (It might not be for everyone, especially if you dont like sour flavors.) But if you are an IPA fan, you will find that the flavors meld beautifully together. 

The feel is very fizzy, very dry, and very thick. It isnt a choker, but it rewards you for taking time with it. This beer is quite unique: the balance between the horsey qualities and the bitter/sweet hops work remarkably well together. Its actually a rather challenging beer: it tunes up the old taste buds. Ive had it before, but today Im digging it probably more than ever.

Cloudy orange. Yeasty spicy aroma. Flavor has some sweetness and a lot of malt body. Slight faint hops on the finish. Late on the palate is a yeast wildness that is slightly funky. Mostly belgian and very little pale ale here.

750 ml corked,caged bottle. Cloudy honey gold color topped by thick, bubbly off-white head. Pleasant citrus fruit malt aroma reminiscent of clementines. Upfront, the first taste is of bittersweet grapefruit, hints of wheat malt and citrusy hops. An underlying yeastiness is present throughout. the pale malts and bitter hops balance nicely. Finishes clean and dry. Very refreshing and drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 12 oz. Hazy peach color with a 5 inch spongy head. Aroma of mango, apricot, wheat bread, spicy clove gum, and light resin. Taste is clove, peppery citrus zest, orange blossom honey, earthy white grape must, evergreen resin, and lightly toasted wheat bread. Light-medium body is way too fizzy, but well balanced, ending on a nice dry note. Definitely the best Belgian, and only the second good beer Ive had amongst the10 or so brews Ive tried from this brewery.

Bottle. Yeasty aroma, with some honey and a hint of herb garden. Cloudy dull honey color with a big ice cream cone head. Very tangy initial, smooth dry mid, final dissipates with dry yeastiness. Light, slick, and very fizzy.  Through Im not a big fan of this style, its quite nicely done. A pleasant, smooth interpretation.

Draft. Poured a cloudy medium orange color. The head was white with decent retention and lacing. Pleasant nose with clove, ginger, flaky pastry, orange, and tropical fruit notes. Medium bodied and delicately sweet. Flavors followed the nose. Great beer.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours hazy golden with some yeast that settles to the bottom of the glass with fluffy white head that dissapates fairly quickly.  Good lacing, medium body, good carbonation, and spicy hop aroma.  Taste is tropical fruite, spicy hops, some pine, and tart yeast.  Lots of flavor.
I am not the biggest Belgian fan. This has a great nose, nice lemon taste. Perfect balance across the board.
very drinkable dynamic Belgian Pale Ale. I would pick this up again especially if I want something that is more on the belgian/pilsner malt side of pale ales.

750ml bottle, best by 07/12.  Aroma shows some light sweetness and floral, herbal and lightly estery touches up front, with lighter notes of hay, muted spice and citrus.  Lightly hazy medium golden in color with a fluffy, lasting head and thick, intricate lacing, some sediment present as well which was left behind in the bottle.  Flavor is very nicely balanced, with some very light sweetness and pale malt tones up front, followed by herbal, fruity, very gently bitter hops and lightly doughy, estery yeast character, some very mild spice and lemony citrus appearing towards the finish.  Well-carbonated but creamy and light on the palate, body is medium.  Plenty drinkable.
Good easy drinking belgian ale.  Im starting to fall in love with lighter belgian ales.  Amazingly drinkable and lightly sweet up front with a drying lightly hopped finish.

On tap at Taco Mac. Pours gold with a medium head. The aroma is grapefruit, hay, pepper, and lemon. The flavor is fairly bitter, with a nice sweetness. The palate is medium to heavy, sticky, and fairly effervescent. Overall, this is a flavorful, bitter, yeasty ale.
Light Belgian cardboardy aroma. Light belgian flavors. Some hops and a bitter finish

Tap. Pours mostly clear gold with average, fizzy white head; decent retention and good lacing. Aroma is straw and biscuit malt, grassy and floral hops, citrus fruit, herbs, and light pine. Flavor is balanced hops (light bitterness) and lightly sweet malt with good supporting citrus esters. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.
Draft. Rich O's. Aroma is minty, floral, piney, eucalyptus. Color is gold with a thin dissipating head. Flavor is lemony, grainy malt, bitter.

pours translucent beer bottle orange with a large thick foamy-creamy head, lots of active CO2 streams. Inviting orange/tangerine citrus on the nose. Ultra creamy mouthfeel, sharp sweetness (8/10) up front, tastes of grapefruit peel, medium malts, caramel, and quickly transitions in a very aggressive dry & hoppy finish which tires out my palate too quickly. Medium complexity, medium depth, okay transitions, good carry, okay drinkability. 1/4 through and my palate is exhausted.
Pours dark copper draft at frasca.  Good sticky head.  Aroma is fantastic. Floral and citrus aroma and taste.  Not very hoppy.  Not a fan of Belgium style but this is a good beer
Smooth, with the perfect amount of hops and aftertaste. A pale ale on the lighter side.
Nose is slightly saisony belgian yeast with pineapple sweetishness.  Taste follows the nose, some good hop bitterness, crisp malt, real good shit.

Tap. Pours a cloudy orange with a medium tan head. Aroma is light yeast with generous hops. Flavor is yeast, malt, caramel, cloves, bananas, and a light hoppy finish. Medium body with medium carbonation. A well-done, balanced brew.
Bottle purchased Rochester at World of Beers. Pours a cloudy amber like colour, fast acting big white head, fair amount of lacing left behind. Smells Belgianesk Tastes light and rather smooth.

Pours a hazy orangish color with a robust light tan head. Lacing was abundant. The nose is citrus (orange peel) and spice. Belgian yeast complemented by just the right amount of hops provides a delightful and refreshing taste. There is slightly bitter finish/aftertaste.The mouthfeel is medium with just a bit of carbonation. Want to drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at The Long Room, NY, NY. Pours a cloudy orange-copper with an average size lasting creamy white head. Decent lacing. Aroma of Belgian yeast, herbs, light herbal hops, some light sweetness, perfumy notes, honey and more. Flavour of Belgian yeast, grassy & fruity hops, herbs, pepper, honey and more. Medium bodied. Alcohol is hidden. Good stuff, I liked it.

-- Rated via Beer Buddy.

12oz bottle poured into snifter. Goldish color with dark brown tints. Big  fluffy head. Aroma  is  mostly hoppy with hints of slight orange citrus. Flavor is somewhat dry but has a nice malt presence.

from Mondial de la Bière 2012, Strasbourg - cloudy dark orange beer with a persistent white head; nice lacework; yeasty with notes of oranges and candi sugar; highly carbonated and slightly chewy palate; some tart acidity and a decent bitterness; quite dry and pretty short fruity hoppy finish

Hazy but bright orange beer under off-white head. Fruity nose with oranges and orangepeel, yeasty. Drier taste than the nose, still mainly orangey-fruity. Very highly carbonated, aftertaste being utterly neutral. Nice enough, if much fruitier-American than one would expect from a bolleke or Palmke...  Merci aan ChrisA!
Sweet citrus aroma.  Light cloudy orange appearance.  Sweet citrus taste  with faint hoppy finish.  Very easy to drink.  A fruity pale ale.

Nice pale ale. Dark amber with a thin head. Shy nose, but some dank hops come through. Medium bodied with malt flavors on the mid palate, but balanced with some citrus fruit. Subtle, yet present hops on the finish.

Beer pours hazy, honey color with a voluminous, egg white colored head that is totally retained.  Aroma is quite compelling with big yeast notes of leather, earth, and band aid.  Carbonation is very lively.  Flavor is sweet with a bitter finish.  Finish is quite dry as well.  This is really good beer.  Excellent job by Ommegang.

Very foamy 5 finger head that lingers for a while! Aroma gives the impression of a very hoppy beer, while the actual flavor is a very rich & well balanced combination of Citrus Hops, Yeasts, Bananas, Cloves, and Malts. Definitely one of my favorite Belgian Style Ales!

was in the mood for something I could drink while on the bbq that was a little easy  on the hops.  Pours straw colour with active white head.  Some citrus notes on the nose.  Nice light refreshing taste mainly pineapple.  This hit the spot.  Hops were subtle  and left no real aftertaste.  Nice crisp easy drinking brew.  Really enjoyed it.
Tap - Sweet peach aroma little or no head dissenting quickly.  Fairly clear honey hue.  An unusual bitterness, very dry along with the usual Belgian flavors.  This combination does not work for me.

12oz bottle poured into goblet.  Best by date of 6/2012.
Aroma: banana, barnyard, funk, hay, lemongrass, coriander
Appearance: golden yellow color.  clear pour.  tons of bubbles rising.  1 finger of white head that lingered to the end of the glass.  laces glass well.
Taste: medium sweet, mild sour, hardly any bitter
Palate: finish is mild sweet, medium sour, and mild bitter.  funkiness comes out here.  Lively carbonation.  medium body, creamy texture.  
Overall:  I like the funkiness that the belgian yeast is contributing.  Mouthfeel on this one is great and so is the appearance.  The aromas are enticing.  Just a bit of the aftertaste that I think could be better.  Very solid beer though.  I dont know if I would intentionally seek this beer out again but I like it.  Bought in a sampler pack so I have one more left.

On tap at the Gingerman.  The look is clear, orangish in color, and has an off white head.  The smell is sweet, slightly spiced, fruits, touch of hops, and year.  The taste is clean, refreshing, fruits, sweet, and pretty good.

(bottle)  Pours a dark hazy gold color with a very large off-white head that immediately filled the entire glass with foam.  This one certainly takes a bit to pour, but it looks nice.  Aroma is strong of pizza crust, lime zest, canned mandarin orange slices, and something else that I cant quite put my finger on, but it doesnt smell all that pleasant.  Flavor isnt all that appealing either, with just a subtle sweet bread dough flavor followed up by some bitter grapefruit hops that taste faintly soapy.  A glimmer of orange appears between the bread and bitterness, which makes this a bit more interesting.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is lively.  Ill have to give this one a re-rate at some point, as the bottle I had was over a year old, and Im thinking this is one that would taste best fresh.

It has an awesome aroma full of standard, complex belgian notes.  It also pours like a belgian - a hazy gold with a very thick white head.  The taste is pretty well balanced.  The hops hit you at all stages but they are not overwhelming.  The belgian notes develop into a complex character up front, followed by a strong hop flavor, and finishes smooth.  A nicely done beer!

750ml. bottle shared with Quevillon. The color is a hazy honey with a thick white heaf and nice lace. The aroma is of citruis fruits and also some sweet fruits like peaches. The taste  also of citrus fruits that give it a bit of a bitter taste.The malt and the sweet fruits are all well balanced, with the added yeast.It leaves a nice tingling feeling in your mouth.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 (750ml bottle) Golden orange, bubbling body, slightly hazy, with a medium off-white head that leaves lace on the glass. Fruity, sweet malt aroma; pear, honey, grape. Light to medium body with lots of bubbling carbonation. Flavor has yeast, light to medium orange/cirtus hops; peach, light vanilla, peppery, herbal, a little musty. Finish leaves an underwhelming last impression.

Pleasant banana smell, clove, vanilla wafer. Soft palate. Nice belgian.
A bit of hop. Nice blend of sweet and bitter.
12 o.z. bottle from a Ommegang multipack; abnormally golden and frothy; Less sweetness than expected.  Good but not great
Tap. Hazy golden with big foamy head.  Smells kind of grape fruity and orangey and like cilantro. Tastes kind of lemony and sweet in a dry way. Light. Some nice light biter build up.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange gold color. Fluffy small white head. Aroma of fruit and citrus, grapefruit. Clean bitter palate, with soft citrus and spicy clove flavors. Very well balanced. I liked the finish, which was both sweet and bitter. Very nice beer.
Tap from brewery. Nice grassy hop up front and through the middle, with a cereal backing. Pours yellow with good lacing. Strong carbonation.
Thick, dense head poured from a tap. Sweet, hoppy pale ale. Tangy fruity notes. Thin mouth feel.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $2.99 Very good!

Bottle pours golden blond with large foamy head. Belgian yeast, bread, floral, clove, pepper. Moderately sweet and approaching moderate bitterness. Mostly saison with a hint of pale ale. I was surprised at how much l like this one.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold with a huge white long-lasting head.  Aroma of yeast, citrus, malt, and florals.  Taste is similar.  Well balanced.  Excellent.
Cloudy copper colour. Fruity and yeasty nose. Rich malty flavours. Classic Belgian pale ale, but a little more fruity.
Its a Belgian with a bit of a kick to it, enough to make me like this beer even though I dont really like Belgian beer too much.

Bottle. The pour was a hazy golden orange with an average sized (1-2 finger) white frothy head that lasted throughout, reducing slowly down to a large foamy cap which produced excellent sheets of sticky lace.

The aroma was of a grain malt, an herbal hop and a musty yeast with notes of citrus (lemon) and a bit of clove.

The taste was malty with a slight hint of wheat and a note of citrus at first and then had a strong yeasty taste with a good dose of spice at the end. The flavor lasted only a short time which was kind of disappointing, as this was one tasty brew.

Mouthfeel was right in the middle of light and medium in body with a smooth creamy texture and a good lively carbonation. 

Overall an extremely good tasting brew with a low alcohol content for a Belgian Ale, which makes this a beer I could drink all day long

$2.50 at my local beer store. Poured into a tulip

A - Light golden color with some haze. 2 finger head creamy and pretty

S - Bread, brown sugar and hops

T - Intense hops which are misleading for this being a Belgian Pale Ale. Milky and creamy aftertaste and nice floral notes.

M - 100% bubbles on a mouth swish, medium bodied, hoppy and dry finish.

O - Drinkable but not terrific.

Served at a good temperature and with a large, fluffy, frothy, billowy, cream colored head and some lace. Color is a clear amber with a couple of lazy bubble trails. Aroma is a traditional Belgian blonde, spicy, malt, a bit of fruit, not overly sweet. Body is ok and carbonation is a little on the flat side. Finish is similar to flavor and on the short side. Beer promises huge dividends and is excellent, but seems somehow as if it should be better.

Light pale amber color with a small white head. Nose is a bit hoppy and malty.  Taste is very crisp an clean with a nice spiciness from the yeast. Theres a pretty creamy thick mouthfeel. Overall its very easy drinking and tasty.

Pours a lightly hazed gold with a big creamy white head. Nice soft musk and yeast, soft wheat with a hopy aroma. Medium bodied light and gently sweet with a nice amount of wheat and a bit of fruity citrus. Crisp finish with spear mint.

Nice golden pour, white head.  Aroma is subtle fruit and hops. Flavor similar. Nice full palate. Good finish.

Another solid beer from these guys Bottle. Pours a lightly hazed gold with a big creamy white head. Nice soft musk and yeast, soft wheat and a very faint dry hop aroma. Medium bodied light and gently sweet with a nice amount of wheat and a bit of fruity citrus. Crisp finish with apple

Pale yellow gold, small white head. Citrus hop nose, slight light fruit. Very light body, delicate flavors, hope spice mixed with pine, with very subtle belgian yeast flavors. Surpringly great session beer,doesnt quite fit a category, but great nonetheless.

how did i miss this one? from a bottle it smells clean and strong.  surprisingly looks like a good generic belgian with all its streams of co2 and such. aroma of mild citrus permeates the air. quite strong and a little unrefined on the buds. initially seem to want to come across like a gentlemanlike beldgy but loses it on the way there. seems a little too hopped for a regular beldgy.  big strong bitter medicine at times, same with the finish. big rocky foamy head outlasts the drink!  yes, rudely strong moments in the session.

The flavor is also a bit yeasty, but there are notes of hops and a bright fruity presence that is unique among the bready undertones. I found this beer to be very drinkable and refreshing.

Draught, Abraxas.  Hazy dark straw/light amber.  Medium head.  Spicy, leafy hop character is fresh and appetizing.  Malts are light and breezy with a slightly biscuity character.  Has an earthy note kind of like dates but not really.  Good spicy and hoppy character.
Pours a golden yellow with frothy white head. Aroma is cider, green apple, spruce. Flavor is a mix of brown sugar, ginger, grapefruit. Palate is medium with very active carbonation.
Light and tasty.  Good balane of yeast and hops.  Smells great too.  Nice foamy head.  Very good beer.

Draft at abraxas. Lovely luminescent dark gold. Aroma a delicate, sophisticated balance of minerals and flowers, egg shells and kumquat skins. Light, easy going palate belies the complex flavors. We have delightfully rich citrus pith, of the pink grapefruit. Long, lingering, but delicate like a citrus rind sorbetto. Extremely refreshing and also deeply satisfying at the same time. Magnifique!

Not a real big fan of Belgian beers, but it has an interesting combination of sour and hop floral.

750 ml bottle from Randalls. Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a big eggshell white head. A lot of big lace loops in the glass. Aroma of dry, crackery malts, toast, straw, earthy hops, sugar, and floral notes. Flavor of floral hops, dry and sweet malts, toasted sugar, and crackers. Hint of citrus zest. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, floral mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Dry finish. Pretty good but Im not sure I had the freshest bottle.

Appearance was cloudy golden with huge 3 finger bubbling head that last forever and with lacing. Aroma was sweet biscuity yeast and slight citrusy floral  hops. Taste was slightly sweet with a lemony herbal hops in the back in with sticky estery yeasts. Mouthfeel was smooth creamy carbonation that creates a long dryish hoppy finish. Different brew...
Medium body pale ale with lemon, Belgian yeast and hints of tropical fruit.  Medium bitterness from the hops.  Big, robust flavor.

Gulorange, lätt beslöjad öl med vitt skum. Doftar blommigt, lätt kryddigt och söta äpplen. Framförallt äpplena går igenom i smaken med viss kryddighet som balans. Att jag inte ser den som en typisk BPA drar ner betyget.

BPA poured a hazy cloudy golden color.  Head on this one was out of control.  Huge, fluffy and full of craters.  Great retention and lacing throughout the glass.

Smell on this beer had me more then once sticking my nose in the glass.  Loved it.  Nice yeasty aroma mixed in with lemon, citrus, cloves, and other spices.  Like I said, really liked the aroma on this one.

The taste was just as good and powerful.  Yeast was again up front, but lingering behind that was a small dose of bitter hops.  Citrus, lemon, and I thought I tasted some other fruit in there too but it was to small to really tell what it was.  Mix that up with a nice sweet malt background and spices and you have a hell of a taste.  

Mouthfeel was light, crisp, and refreshing.  Ton of carbonation stings the tongue.  The ending was a little mouth puckering dry.
På fat på Darwin´s, Sarasota, Florida. Guldgul öl med ett litet skum. Doftar stort och mycket av mango och citrus. Väldigt kolsyrig, något bitter och smakar citrongräs, koriander och grapefrukt.

35cl bottle - pours hazy orange with copious white foam and some lacing.  Nose is Belgian yeast, fruit and light hops.  Aroma is way hoppier than the nose would suggest.  Taste is still sweet (tartness from the fruit) and civilly hoppy on the back end.  Medium to full body with sticky to thin texture.  I normally dont like hoppy drinks, but this one is done to my liking and Ommegang has done it again by making a wonderful brew (Witt excluded)!  Burpy.

Poured a slightly hazy amber color with a thin offwhite head.  Aroma is strange, like cider with funky notes.  Taste has some cardboard and light fruit.  Tastes a bit off, like I got a bad batch maybe.  Overall interesting, but I dont know.

Pours hazy golden yellow with a large fluffy white head.  Aroma is citrus, mango, bubblegum and florals.  Taste is sweet with lots of tropical sweetness coming through, some tartness.  Nice dry finish.  Overall his was vey wll balanced.

Bomber.  Pours a pale yellow with a largish white head.  Aroma and flavor are tropical fruit, peaches, rich malt, muted Belgian elements, slightly spicy hops.  A really wonderful beer.  Drinkable and flavorful.
Pours a hazy orangish yellow.  Lots of soapy bubbles with moderate lacing.  Aroma is light citrus hops.  Taste is complex.  Hops, orange, bready malts, and alcohol.  Dry.  Very nice.

On tap at the Dutch. Golden hue capped by a nice head with good retention, slightly cloudy. Smell is full of flower and light cracker. Well balanced by light malt, slightly cutting bitterness from flower, light grass and hay. Light to medium bodied..

Rated via BeerBuddy

Shared at a tasting, pours orange to yellowish slightly hazy with a nice head, aroma of limey hops, some herbs, a touch of onion spiciness, apricot and yeasty tones are present, dry with flavors of peach, apples acidity some floral notes and some herbs, medium bodied, nice
A dark yellow beer with a medium frothy head.  The aroma is yeast, citrus, and tropical fruit.  The flavor is floral, fruity, and spicy, an interesting beer.

Hazy orange pour with a thick, dense head that leaves a ton of sticky lacing. Aroma was orange and a bit spicy. Taste was very similar with a nice subtle bitterness and maltiness. Nice carbonation and a dry finish. Very enjoyable.

12/30/11. 12oz bottle courtesy watson1977! Hazy orange pour with a nice, big, thick, khaki head that sticks forever and laces a ton. Floral, citrusy aroma with bits of lemon peel and orange zest. Very nice flavor as well with light sugars and more floral and citrus aspects. This is quite pleasant. Nice!

355 mL bottle.  Hazy brown-orange with a tremendous off-white head.  Notes of c-hops in the aroma (!) along with some spicy Belgian yeast.  The flavour is a little more indistinct.  Nothing really stands out, but there are more hops here. Everything works nicely to make a very drinkable beer.

Light funky aroma, yeasty with some floral hop notes, some orange peel and mild coriander. Sweet malt notes, toast. Dark golden amber clear with thin foamy white lacing head. Medium watery body with medium-high carbonation. Starts fairly dry with lots of hop bitterness, though not overtaxing. Yeasty astringency, sweet pale malt and orange peel. Carbonic acidity and some alcohol sweetness, too. Finish is bitter with hops and some yeast astringency. Nice dry funky after, and a nice Belgian ale.

Bottle, many thanks zvikar, medium creamy head, hazy orange colour, aroma of rose petals, citrus, a melange of tropical fruits and a touch of spiciness, flavour of white fruits with herbal tea and spiciness, medium and quite empathic bitterness. A great and original marriage of american hops and belgian yeast.

On tap @ Specific Gravity, Salisbury Md-Clear orange pour w/an off white head. Sweet citrus hop aroma. Has a hop bite up front, followed by a belgian style finish w/candied sugar, some bubblegum, some colander/spice, and a little bit of a malt finish. Bottle at home, out of my Maudite glass. Pours cloudy orange, thick white head, quickly dissipated, quite nice lacing. Nose is nicely hoppy, some sweet yeasty notes, tart grain, some peppery spiciness. Flavours of bread, tart grapefruit/hops, very nice balance; I could drink this every day.

Well brewed with great drinkability factor though lacking some minor notes of floral aroma.
Pours light golden with slight foamy white head.  Little bit of flowery aroma. Strong bitterness and sweet taste. Tartness in the aftertaste.
Draft at sticky lips. Pours a clear light amber with virtually no head. Aroma of hay and hops. Clean bwlgian taste... kinda like a hoegaarden but hopped up. Nice.

Bottle; cloudy golden with heavy light yellow head; aroma-citrus, yeast, bread, pineapple; taste-medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour,average carbonation. Pineapple and orange coming through. Quite good

Bottle. Pours a amberish. Nice white head. bread, dough, banana, hops, citrus, fruit. medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lively carb. Not bad at all
RBESG August 2011, White Horse on Parsons Green. Dark golden with  a small white head. Aroma dominated by banana esters and spicy phenols. Sweet fruity flavour with some phenols.

12 oz bottle. A simpler offering from Ommegang, but still true to form with a nice blend of a crisp, biscuity Belgian ale with American pale hops. As usual, the pour is beautiful with bountiful starch white, pillowy head, clumpy lacing and retention, and a bright pale orange body. In the nose, a good amount of doughy dinner roll, cherries, mixed sweet fruits, minor funk, along with some floral and citrus hop. The feel here is nice. Medium body, slightly chewy with the combo of bread and floral hop, and a bit of tangy sweetness through out. More fruity esters come out in flavor, but the profile follows and the aroma quite well. Overall, this is high quality session ale from a remarkably consistent brewer.
Yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma of biscuit, spice, banana and citrus. Taste is yeasty and fruity with a mild bitterness. Medium bodied. Nice, refreshing pale.

Serving glass: Poured from tap into Tulip.

Appearance: Clear copper-amber with nice off white head.

Aroma: Quite hoppy with grapefruit, tropical fruit and some spiciness. Biscuit, clove and banana as well.

Taste: Similar to the aroma with a biscuit malt backing and nice clove and banana yeast undercurrent. Nice layer of tropical hops on top with mild bitterness and spiciness.

Similar in my experience to a Blue Moon, a bit hoppyer than that. Citrus flavors, golden/orange color. Crisp, clear, and clean.
Poured cloudy orange with foamy white head. Smelled of citrus fruits, like pineapple. Also has some ginger on the nose. Tastes like citrus, with high carbonation.

A creamy dense head of a pour with great retention. The nose plays a tone of spicy banana, floral hops, and zesty caramel. Dry, and leaves a pungent bitter aftertaste that will linger. (oh yeah, it was dry hopped :)) A good body of a BPA all around!

Pours a cloudy golden amber, with a touch of orange. The head is only slightly off white, thick and very long lasting. The nose is citrus bubble gum with a floral undertone. Pours hazy golden yellow with a huge white head and lots of lace.  Aroma is of Belgian yeast, malts, citrus, and something funky.  Very smooth flavor, lots of yeast, malts, spices, some herbs, citrus and a little resiny.

Bottle. Hazy medium brass with a thick and large rocky head which is slightly tinted yellow. The nose is funky leather with some light lemons and a little bit of fresh cut green wood. There is also a little bit of yeasty dough. The taste is initially sugary sweet with a little bit of orange peels. There is yeast and hints of woody funk at the end. The body is surprisingly light. Earthy aroma with a prominent hop presence along with some zesty spice, pale malt and light fruit notes. Lots of grassy pine along with some coriander and pepper followed by hints of apple and pear.

Medium bodied with some tight carbonation and a strong earthy hop presence up front that lingers over the sweeter notes into a dry finish. Slightly floral with some grassy pine and faint citrus fruit complimented by some peppery spice. Only slightly dry but not very bitter. Countered by some pale malt and crisp, light fruit. Overall, the palate is surprisingly full and its easy to drink but its not terribly flavorful or interesting.

Bottle. Light to moderate malt notes of grain and straw, moderate pine, perfume and citrus peel for the hops, light to moderate suede leather and soap for the yeast, with juicy fruit gum and clove in te background. Poured from 12 oz bottle. Cloudy gold, very attractive beer.   Massive foamy thick head.  Citrus aroma with some sweetness in background. Tart taste with bite after swallowing. Fairly high carbonation.  Some clove in aftertaste.  A great Belgian style ale.

Very cloudy golden yellow in appearance followed by a very, very thick head.  Sweet citrus flavors upfront with a trailing malty yeasty bitterness. On tap at Alex and Ika in Cooperstown, NY.  Poured a hazy and bubbly gold, and tastes pretty much as advertised.  Not extremely hoppy, a little bit of spice and pepper in it, but not overwhelming.  Tastes almost like a really light tripel.  Might be a bit of stretch, but I think it might be my favorite Ommegang beer.

Straight pour from a pry-off 12oz bottle to large wine glass, package date 03/25/11best by date 03/2012

Appearance (4/5): Glowing, hazy golden body with a dense, 2 ½ finger, bone white head slowly fading to a ½ finger head. Good, moderate lacing.

Smell (7/10): Light, bready, crisp malt scents with a characteristic Ommegang yeast noteslightly fruity, slightly floral, and biscuity.

Taste (8/10): Crisp, bready malt with grassy hops following right behind. Hop profile sticks around, moving from grassy to a very light citrus flavor backed by that crisp, biscuity malt base. The hops open up a bit as it goes on, ranging from grassy to lemony, until that end of the hop profile sits on top of the crisp biscuity malt body. Very tasty, very light and very drinkable, actually.

Mouthfeel (5/5): Smooth, very fine carbonation that sticks around, light and velvety but not thick at all. Really excellent feel in the mouth.

Overall (17/20): Not many of Ommegangs beers are as light and quaffable as this is, they tend to be better for savoring and sipping. This is a very nice, approachable Belgian pale, and a good introduction to the style.

UPDATE (9/5/11): Had this super-fresh at the brewery recently, and I have to say that when the hops are freshest, they have a very bright, bitter presence that really turns it into a somewhat different beer; its good to very good if the hops have faded a bit, but very good to excellent when theyre bright and fresh!
