From the 12 fl. oz. bottle stamped PKG on 04/04/11 Best By 04/2012. The pour is a cloudy yellow with a frothy, slowly disolving off-white head.  Some sediments. The aroma is full of hops and sweet fruit.  The body is relaxingly smooth. The taste has a lot of sweetness in it.  It is a likeable brew.

On tap, pours hazy gold yellow. Smooth belgian ale with hay and some floral hops slightly creamy mouth feel with good carbonation. Faint funkiness and a moderate amount of bitterness in finish. This is a good and very tried and true BPA.

750 mL bottle from the brewery, served in a tulip. Pours hazy orange-golden with a tall white head. The head remains and leaves lots of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of hay, fruit, herbs, Belgian yeast and a touch of citrus. The flavour is well balanced, moderately sweet and moderately bitter with pale malts, grass and citrus. The finish is incredibly long and hoppy-herbal. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent Belgian-style pale. A very nice summer beer, appropriate for a cool evening out on the patio. Very well done. 2011-08-12

P: rich wet-straw/gold.  multiple fingers of thick off-white head receeding
to a good half-inch, supported by minor carbonation.

A: sweet tangerine citrus

F: solid tangerine/citrus flavor. minor resiny.  pine-like notes in after.
hop bitterness in after-taste.

M: thin, light.  some carbonation on tongue

O: just a bit bitter, which detracts from the wonderful early tangerine
sweetness.

I enjoyed having this at Floods in Stroudsburg with the lovely citrus hop tones which seem to mix perfectly with the Belgian yeast which adds a bit of funkiness to it but not a whole lot though. The yeast seems to add more of a fruit tone and spiciness.

A wonderfully light and refreshing brew. Big frothy head out of the bottle and into the glass. A hazy golden color. Lots of citrus and spice in the aroma and on the palate. Yeasty flavors. Slightly tart and bitter finish. Good stuff.

750 ml bottle purchased at City Market Onion River Co-Op, drank on August 5, 2011. Honey golden hazy, good head. Hoppy aroma of tropical fruit, quite dry, with notes of Belgian yeast. Yeasty slightly sweet, tropical fruit and citrus hops, a little spicy, bitter lemon. Another well done dry hop Belgian ale!
Bottle, 12 ounces, purchased at the Four Firkins in St. Louis Park, MN. Nice thick head. Golden straw color. Crisp and fruity flavor. Mild Belgian yeast flavors.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, purchased at Wegmans during a trip to Syracuse, savoured on August 13 2011; eye: golden, clear, minimal effervescence, voluminous white head made up of rather large bubbles, nice lacing; nose: yeast, floral hops, light perfumy, spices, pepper; mouth: hops, yeast, floral hops, spices, pepper, light orange, pine, finale in hops with presence of pepper, medium body, below-average carbonation, mildly bitter,lightly sweet, a bit thinoverall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, achetée chez Wegmans lors dun voyage à Syracuse, savourée le 13 août 2011; il : dorée, claire, effervescence minime, mousse blanche abondante formée de bulles plutôt grosses, bonne dentelle; nez : levure, houblon floral, léger parfumé, épices, poivre; bouche : houblon, levure, houblon floral, épices, poivre, léger orange, pin, finale en houblon avec présence de poivre, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement amère, légèrement sucrée, un peu mince; en résumé : bien
Appropriate head for the style with the color of the beer being straw-like. Finishes slightly dry and citrusy. Slight hints of Belgian yeast (would have liked more).
Draught at The White Horse, London. Clear deep golden. Weak belgian yeast aroma, slightly earthy. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with low bitterness.

Tap @ White Horse. Pours cloudy amber with small off white head leaving lace. Aroma is yeasty, fruity, sweetish, raisins and malty. Flavor is crispy, fruity, caramel, sweet, malty, citric and bitter. Finishes fruity bitter.

Draught at White Horse.
Cloudy orange coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of hops and grass.
Fruity flavour of hops and grass with notes of caramel and pine needles.
Hoppy finish.

Keg at the White Horse, RBESG 2011. 
Yeasty, slightly funky Belgian yeast nose, amber malts. Spicy, fruity, nicely yeasty and earthy.

355ml bottle from jsprime. orange with a lasting off white head with great retention and awesome lacing. fresh citrus hop and yeasty nose. flavour is quite hoppy, creamcicle, background malt. soft on the palate, not overly complex. really nice stuff.

Keg at the White Horse. It pours cloudy orange, with a thick foamy white head. The nose is Belgian yeast, hay, pear, pineapple and some herbs. The taste is very fruity: orange, pear, pineapple, red apple, tangerine, as well as: hay, straw, grass, Belgian yeast and some spice, with a bitter-dry finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and good balance. Smooth, gentle alcohol warmth lingers throughout. A very fruity and tasty Belgian-style ale.
Draught at The White Horse, London. FRuity, hoppy, yeasty aroma. Fresh fruity, hoppy flavor. Yeasty notes, some spices. A beer with a nice balance.

On tap at White Horse during their American beer festival.
Thick creamy white head.  Slightly hazy amber pour.  Citrus aroma.  Very nice!

I dont get a lot in the aroma, but I sure get a lot in the beer! Has a nice light Sierra-Nevada like flavor but with added Belgian spice. Really quite good. After the Squatters Hells Keep (which I didnt like) Im glad I had one more to finish off the night.

12 oz bottle. Hazy orange-gold, over-vigorous pour filled the entire glass with head. Took 10 minutes to pour the entire beer. Aroma is delicious: hops & belgian yeast. Flavor is fruity with pineapple, orange and a touch of yeast, then a nice hop flavor and mild bitterness. Slightly bitter aftertaste-- not unpleasant though. An amazing combination of two great style, and a very nice complex beer from Ommegang-- perhaps their best offering?
Tap. Mostly clear light orange pour with a moderate white head. Black pepper and slight citrus hop on the nose. Similar taste. Some yeast in here as well. Pretty good.

750ml corked and caged bottle poured into a Trappist glass at 45°.  Color is a hazy gold with very active carbonation and a tall thick head.  Aroma of hops, Belgian yeast and a hint of skunk in the back.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor comes in fruity with pineapple, orange and a touch of yeast, then a nice hop flavor and mild bitterness.  In the after taste the bitterness grows, then as it fades out the fruit comes back in.  Overall its a great brew with an incredibly complex flavor.

12 oz. bottle into an Ommegang glass. Honey colored with an amazing head. Its thick and chunky and leaves huge gobs of lacing. One of the nicest Ive seen. The aroma is very intense, as it even manages to escape this thick foamy cap. Smells of banana, Good and Plenty candy, bubble gum, and black pepper. The body is medium with high carbonation. Plenty of juicy fruit flavors including peach and pineapple, some clove, fresh bread, and the distinctive Ommegang yeast. The finish is long and dry and moderately hoppy, with some nice spice flavors developing a minute or so after the swallow. Very complex. Great offering from Ommegang.

On tap at the Bottom Lounge. Pours a cloudy, golden-orange colored body with an inch thick, dense and frothy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of lacing. Aroma has a good amount of spicy hops with a light sweetness up front. Lots more American citrus (pineapples and tangerines) comes in along with some Belgian yeast, grass, clove, a moderate caramel sweetness, and some banana esters. Flavor is similar. A mix of sweet and spicy hops up front with some herbal spice, grass, and a touch of floral. Some more distinct Belgian yeast comes in along with a light clove spice and banana as well as a balancing caramel with a moderate sweetness and a touch of bread. Fruity citrus oranges and pineapples increase a bit in juiciness towards the end as this finishes spicy and sweet while drying with a medium-light bitterness. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium, smooth body and soft, creamy, moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid beer. Nicely hopped and balanced with a pleasant Belgian yeast. Good mix of spicy and sweet while staying clean and easy drinking.

Appearance: Hazy, golden yellow. White head with thick lacing.
Aroma: Citrus (orange, grapefruit), mango, perfume, candy
Taste: Citrus, cherries? a little grassy in the end. Overall fruitiness. Hop forward, but balanced.
Mouthfeel: dense carbonation, medium body.
Overall: Quite enjoyable. More complex as it warms in the glass. Lots going on.

Pours a hazy orange with nice head and lacing, smells wonderful...ahh man, tastes nothing like it smells. Taste is definitely lacking and weak. Shoot, if only it tasted like it smells. Argh, what a shame.

Honey colored and cloudy. White foamy head. Banana taffy, apricot, and alcohol line the estery but fairly dull nose. Belgain yeast aroma distinctive.  Medium-to-light body. Carbonation is the same. Texture is a little slick. Its a nice offering from Ommegang. I pleasant Belgian take on an American standard. My only qualms would be with the texture and carbonation levels. But otherwise, very tasty.
bottle shared by murphym45 - arouma is spicy, nice caramel malts. Dryer than expected. spicy coriander, cloves, peaches and crisp apples.
11.07.16 sampled @ vbf clear golden hazy white head.  A: spicy, i get some pear, floral, citrusy. F: light finish is bitter and medium long. O: great !

Draft at the fantastic cafe at the brewery.  This Belgian Ale is golden in color with aromas of hops and yeast.  The flavors are grass, mint, spice and yeast with a nice hop finish.  This beer is refreshing, crisp and delicious.

bottle pours a hazy orange gold gradient with fluffy finger of off white head.  Aroma is soft but nuanced, with hoppy notes of citrus,sweet, malty / yeasty notes of angel food cake (sweet white bread), whipped cream.  Medium bodied, with a very smooth, fluffy feel.  Flavor is at first sweet and yeasty, then has a soft, nicely done bitterness on the finish, which evolves into a lighter feel with sweet fruits.  Very nice rendition of the style.

12oz bottle. Hazy amber-orange. Ridiculously tall head when I poured just half the beer, I hope this is normal. The glass is 2/3 head, its very fluffy and persistent. Tastes very belgian. It has a sort of toffee tone to complement its obvious citrus-fruit flavor. Spice and hop through the finish. Fun.

Poured a hazy, golden yellow with a nice fluffy head. It says pale ale, but it is so much more. Well balanced and complex with a nice, slightly bitter finish. I never had a pale ale like this in Belgium. This is a great beer.
on tap. weird milky amber pour with little head. yeasty and banana aroma. banana, plum, cherry and yeast flavour with a citrus hop bitter finish. very balanced, fruity and bitter. very good beer.
Good beer.  This Belgian-style pale ale is great for slowly drinking to really enjoy its complex flavors of, yeast, malts, and hops.

On tap at US Beerfest, North Bar, Leeds. Pours a hazy yellow, medium white head. Very fruity aroma, with yeast and a bit of citrus. Taste is wonderful - hoppy, bitter, refreshing with citrus and fruit. Like an IPA but without the malty  foundation youd find in one, which brings the crispness to the fore. Belgian yeast/ester on the dryish finish make a lovely parting gift. Very, very nice indeed, rewardingly complex but refreshing, hits the spot and not stodgy. Mmm.

Whole Foods Market, DC 4-pack ($10): Pours a cloudy orange color with a frothy white head. Belgian yeast, bread, and some hops are all up in that aroma. Pours a slightly hoppy with this weird burnt hop aftertaste. A little bit sweet it is, I say. Mellow mouthfeel with some light carbonation. Good fruity flavors. Good balance methinks.
Pours a transparent amber with a thin white head. Piney aroma woodsy yeast and bready malt. Medium sweet and lightly bitter. Palate is smooth and sticky.

Pours a nice hazy golden color with a lot of effervescent bubbling and an enormous tight rocky white head that leaves good lacing on the glass. The aroma is full of fruit, banana, melon, citrus, its a damn fruit of the month club up in my glass. There are some dank hop notes and a little touch of damp cellar in there as well. The flavor is this really great interplay between fruity esters, hop bitterness, & citrus hop flavor. The beer starts of with a sort of sweet note but it doesnt take long before it dries out and the finish leaves you with almost a brut like sensation. The malt isnt really hidden here, but its in the background. Mild notes of cracker and honey do wonders for the whole balance of the beer. Instead of bringing sweetness to the table (that with this yeast profile would overwhelm) the malt brings subtle and complimentary flavors. 
This is a genuine marriage between Belgian and North American style brewing where neither really take center stage but rather nicely play off one another. I think a funky version of this would really be something else entirely.

750ml bottle. Golden with a thick foamy head and some flaky sediment towards the end. Aroma of citrus, light fruit, musty cellar and some rock candy. The flavor is tart yeast upfront with a firm bitterness and light sugar sweetness, very balanced. Medium to light body with active carbonation and a clean, refreshing finish. Great Belgian Pale, the fruity hops and base beer work very well together.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 I never bought this in the 750 ml because of the price, but the 4-packs are reasonable. Super fluff head...too much, really. Great Cascade aroma. Im not necessarily a fan of hoppy Belgians as I think either the hops or yeast should shine on their own, but this works. Pretty strong citrus flavor, although it lacks the malt backbone of an IPA. Definitely more bitter/dry than sweet.
[Bottle] Densely clouded light amber, strong head formation and retention. Malty, slightly peppery nose. Malty palate, mild yeasty spice, some coriander. Mild citrussy, lemony hops in the finish.

Enjoyed on tap at the Bottom Lounge in Chicago, IL while watching the band Ceremony who creeped me the hell out but were awesome.  Appearance pretty clear orange/amber with thich creamy white head.  Aroma of a nice hop/malt balance with Belgian yeast backing.  Taste really is like a Belgian ale / APA hybrid.  A bit of clove with nice balanced profile.  Goes down smooth, true session beer.  Very good, would enjoy again.

Pale orange gold, nice white head, slight haze after sediment kicks up.  Aroma is citric and phenolic, aromas of Belgian yeast and American hops.  Flavor is a match, pepper, hint of clove, light malts, and citric hop finish.  The hops and yeast play fairly well here, but not my favorite overall.  Still not completely sold for the most part on these pairings.

pours a hazy golden color with nice white fluffy head.  Mostly citrus nose with a slight hint of pine, little bit of sweetness.   Real nice flavor, nothing too biting, crisp, hint of citrus (lemon), slightly dry, nice palate.  This is lighter than their Rare Vos and Abbey and more flavorful than their Witte and Hennepin.  This is a very nice addition to the Ommegang line up.

tap at Hoppy Monk in El Paso, TX-pours dark orange clear with a small soapy white head.  nose of esters, floral hops, and yeasty fruit.  love the nose here!  flavors of floral hops, yeasty twang (lite funky esters)dry lemon and slightly herbal character.  pretty complex for a small beer like this.  long floral herbal finish lovely easy drinking pale form this brewery!
Gold pour. Fluffy white head. Yeasty and lemony aroma. Flavor is lightly sweet, lemony, yeast. Good.

Be careful when opening it - my sample popped like a champagne bottle and fizzed from here to California, and Im in Georgia right now! Aroma is mainly  fruity, rather crisp with a hint of malt. It pours a slightly hazy solar yellow with a thick, frothy, rather persistend white head that leaves considerable lacing. Flavor is crisp, more fruity than malty, with a woody overtone, and both bitter and sweet hints that balance each other nicely. Mouthfeel is smooth and just a little fizzy, leaving a fruity and hoppy finish.

Medium beige head. Amber body with light carbonation. Spicy coriander and tropical fruit aroma with Belgian yeast notes. Dry-sweet spicy coriander fruity taste with grassy notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mouthfeel. Dryish intensely herbal coriander aftertaste with spicy grassy dandelion notes. Too intensely herbal, really. (0.3l draft at Anchor & Hope, San Francisco.)

Best belgian pale ale i have had!!! pours yellow with some nice fluffy head some sediment. nose is spicy belgian yeast and sweet malts with just enough citrus so u know its there, flavor is a great balance. definatly belgian but has the most hops for this style that I have found. well done!!

6- 17-11 Tap @ Monks.  Ommegang BPA was my first of the night so I dont remember it too well.  I do remember everyone at the bar thought it was too sweet and under hopped.  Thats fine if youre making an American Pale Ale but I appreciated this style.  I thought the malt character was nice, but definitely on the sweeter end.  The hop character was there for me as well.  Not the overly citrusy or piney presentation one might expect in a PA but it was a dirtier, funkier hop which actually worked very well to dry off my palate and balance the sweetness.  I enjoyed this beer but I wouldnt call it my favorite.

Pours a clear gold with some sediment.  A plentiful white head. Aroma contains Belgian spice, sugar sweetness, and some citrus. Taste is grapefruit with caramel candy malt note and finishing with the very dry Belgian yeast character.  Very drinkable.

Pours orange with three and a half fingers of fluffy white head. Smells like bready citrus, grapefruit and orange, and hints of pine. Tastes kind of bready and then mildly citrusy and has something reminiscent of mint or pine on the finish. Medium-bodied with a smooth, wet texture and some mouth-carbonation, Ommegang Belgian-style Pale Ale (BPA) finishes with hints of pine.

A: This one pours a cloudy pale orange/amber color with a couple fingers of white head.

S: Lots of pepper on the nose along with a light citrus peel note. Some undertones of banana and other light fruits, maybe apples, offer up a bit more sweetness. Some bread and cracker malt aroma and a light spiciness overall.

T: A lot of similarities between the the flavor and the aroma. Heavy relaince on bread and cracker malts with a big black pepper flavor. An underlying fruitiness which adds some sweetness and depth. A bit more yeastiness to the flavor than I had expected and not as much citrus peel as anticipated.

M: Medium in body with a medium to high carbonation.

O: This was okay, but nowhere near as good as some of the other Ommegang beers Ive had.

A good Belgian styled beer and on par with what the Belgians are doing. Ommegang is one US brewery that can nail these styles. Aroma was so so. Belgian yeast, light pear and fruit cocktail. Pour was  a light hazy gold with plenty of rising bubbles and a 3 finger white head. Taste was strong and full. Heavy fruit cocktail and bubble gum with a thick mouth feel and not much else coming through. Very sweet. Aftertaste leaves the mouth very fruity. Pear and apple mostly. Medium to light carbonation. Nice beer
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Not typically a fan of the style but I actually enjoyed this.  14 karat hazy pour with a massive ivory head that nearly flowed over the edge of the glass.  Little spatters of lacing inside the glass.  Aroma of spicy hops, white pepper, and lemongrass...lots of yeast as well.  Biscuit, honey, leafy qualities, bittering hops, caramel, and lots of peppery spice.  Medium mouthfeel...ample carbonation.

Sample at Mondial de la Bière (Montréal). Hazy golden body with an average off-white foamy/creamy head. Strong hoppy aroma with malty and grapefruit hints. Fresh, sharp hoppy taste with fruity notes. Ends with a long bitter finish. Very enjoyable.

Tap @ Belmont Station...  Poured pale, golden with a white head.  Nose had some yeast spice with some hop resins.  Nice, lighter body, dry yeast flavors. Floral hop flavors, malt sweetness, finished with a Belgian yeast, bubblegum flavor.

THOUGHTS: The first Ommegang beer Im not totally in love with. Its not awful. It was just not to my taste. The yeast and dry hopping clashed to me. For hops to work in a Belgian beer they need to be a stronger style. Id love to try this without the dry hopping. It did grow on me, but it is still probably my least favorite Ommegang beer. It actually did get quite nice as it warmed even more, but it still wasnt really my cup of tea. It did pair nice with some extra sharp. white cheddar.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a hazy, dark yellow to light orange with a huge, meringue-like, off-white head that mostly, but very slowly diminished and left good, thick and clingy lacing. The aroma had light to moderate light bread and pale malt; a hint of caramel; moderate to heavy pine hops, some citrus hops, less pineapple hops; light to moderate soapy and spicy yeast; and oranges. The initial flavor was lightly sweet, light to moderately bitter and lightly acidic; while the finish was light to moderately sweet, ever so slightly sour and moderately bitter with an average on flavor and long on dry finish. There was pale malt, sort of wheat, pine and citrus hops, yeast, orange rind, very fresh hop flavor without extreme bitterness, hints of pineapple, oranges, slightly minty and herbal hops. The light to medium body was dry with sort of soft, yet tingly carbonation and a dry finish.

Doesnt look much different than a lot of other pale ales but the aroma is of fresh hops with only a hint of yeast.  The flavor is of grapefruit, yeast and slightly dry.  Seeing as this brewery is owned by the same people that make Duvel, I was pleasantly surprised at how different yet great this was in comparison.

A - Pours a slightly hazy golden-orange color with a big two fingers of frothy white head. The head fades slowly down to a still sizeable layer leaving behind some great lacing.

S - The aroma is a mix of some citrus fruits and spices. There is also some nice sweet malts and some strong yeast aromas.

T - Starts off with some citrus fruit flavor and some light spices. There is also some yeast hanging around in the background. Through the middle, the yeast gets a bit stronger and some banana and bread come through. The finish is a mix of citrus, spices, and banana that lingers nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. Has a nice slightly dry character that is especially nice as the beer finishes. The finish has some banana and sweet flavors that linger.

D - Very drinkable. The flavors are really nicely balanced and work together very nicely. Everything works together nicely, and the banana flavor mixed in is really nice.

(12oz bottle packaged on 1/24/2011 served in a Belgian ale tulip) Pours a clear gold with some sediment and a luxurious 4 finger head that slowly disappates and maintains a 1 finger prescence.  Aroma is slight Belgian yeast spice, big caramel candy sugar sweetness, and some minor citrus peel on account of the dry hopping.  Taste is Cascade hops (similar to but on a lesser scale than Sierra Nevada Pale) signature grapefruit, followed by a clean caramel candy malt note and finishing very dry with a whisper of Belgian yeast and lingering grapefruit.  On the palate it is highly effervescent which gives its medium body a full, foamy mouthfeel.  This is a great transition beer for hop maniacs like myself who have an aversion to heavy Belgian yeast but are looking to branch out into the wide world of Belgians.  Solid beer.

Spicy and dry, yet odd and prickly, I cant find much love for Ommegangs BPA.  While it has the appearance of a Belgian brew, I was expecting a more American nose.  The hops are there, but the Belgian yeast hogs the spotlight.  For a Belgian Ale, BPA tastes sparkly but bland and lacking any defined direction, save a little soapy, floral herb twist on the finish.  As a Pale Ale, the hops take their time showing up, and only provide a token appearance before scurrying away, only to reappear in your belches.  The Belgian-style texture doesnt really work with the hoppy leanings, since it scours your tongue before any resinous IBUs can sink in.  Interesting, but not anything close to Ommegang at their best.
Interesting beer.  A little more subtle than I expected from them but nice grassy and herbal notes. Marked by a very dry finish.

12oz bottle, best by April 2011.  Lets see how well this holds up.
Pours lightly hazy yellow/gold with a large three finger foamy white head that holds a very good cap and leaves some rings of lacing behind.

Aroma is orange citrus, some peaches, grassy and herbal, some banana, yeast and bread.  A bit of funk comes out with a strong swirl being the only distractor in an otherwise fine aroma.  Good strength.

Flavor is lemon and orange citrus, banana and a bit of bubblegum, some grassy hops, fair malt sweetness which is balanced by some bitterness on the finish.

Mouthfeel is light-medium bodied, a bit oily, good carbonation.

Well, color me impressed considering this is a bit over one year old and has held up quite well.  Couldnt pass up the single on the discount rack for 99 cents, definitely will seek out a fresh sample and update this review then.

750mL bottle, pours hazy golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma of tropical fruits, yeast and orange peel. Flavour of dry saison-like fumk, champagne yeast and dry tropical fruits. Very nice, though nothing extraordinary.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy golden colour with a white bubbly head. Aroma of orange, butterscotch, tropical fruits, pear, mango. Flavour of tropical fruits, orange peel, citrus hops, pineapple. Quite fruity, light with various layers of flavour. An unpretentious beer.

Appearance:   medium gold, lightly hazy; big cotton candy fluff of white head; tons of lace.  Aroma: slight notes of herbal hops over fresh white bread.  Taste: very much like a typical Belgian blond ale, but minus the sweetness, and with added notes of delicately bitter, earthy hops; didnt get much in the way of citrus.   Finish: smooth, clean, slightly bitter.   Notes: Well-balanced, with a fantastic palate and appearance.  A solidly drinkable beer.

Pale copper pour thin white head light sticky lacing .... aroma is herbal and earthy almost tea like at first with some citrusy and floral hop ....  taste is herbal and earthy sweet malts, citrusy and bitter floral hops, little grassy  .... finish is little malty with the bitter floral hops that lingers slightly .... a solid belgian pale good to session with

Bottle. Stand back, boys, shes a gusher! Or, rather, a foamer, as this poured a cloudy gold with a huge, high, long-lasting cream head. Nose is resinous and dry; theres some citrus and some typical Belgian aroma, but theres also laurel and rosemary.  Lemony on the palate, with malt and bitterness playing counterpoint to the acidity. Mouthfeel is clean, and carbonation is appropriate. Really, really good.

12 oz. bottle.  pours a deep golden with a 3+ finger white head which falls to a 1/4" throughout.  soft citrus hop notes on the nose with some banana and light bubblegum.  for being dry hopped, I would expect more - maybe my bottle is a bit older?  light body - almost watery at times - this really confused me... but the dry hopping comes through here more.  citrus bitter notes linger through from front to back leaving a nice dry bitterness on the back.  some light fruit notes along with more belgian yeast esters come forward.  overall a disappointment... it felt too light in body and nose, but had some redeeming bitterness towards the back.
Wow, I thought this beer was extremely hoppily sweet and great. I had drank about a 6 pack before this one and my palate may have been off.

Probably my least favorite ommegang so far. Has some floral bouquet action on the nose. Pours dark golden from those big ass 25 oz. bottles with a healthy sized white head that leaves a lot of lacing. Nice hop flavor on the tongue which totally dominates the estery Belgian spice notes and the finish was somewhat brash. A confusing experience.

Draft @ Three Penny Taproom. Big white bubbles for head. Hazy orange, with yellow hues around the edges. Awesome aroma of orange and light Belgian spice. Taste is a mouth watering, orange peel and a slight pepper in the finish. Low carbonation and easy to drink. Great on draft. I would order again.

Draft @ Three Penny Taproom. Big white bubbles for head.  Hazy orange, with yellow hues around the edges.  Awesome aroma of orange and light Belgian spice.  Taste is a mouth watering, orange peel and a slight pepper in the finish. Low carbonation and easy to drink.  Great on draft. I would order again.
Yellow with good head.  Some light fruit flavor with a good bit of hops thrown in.  Slightly unique and worth the try.

12 ounce bottle - $2.69 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, orange-gold body with a tall, proud, airy white head. Splotches of sticky lace on the descent.

Smell: Rustic whole-grain sour dough bread accented by traces of sweetness and a rich array of spicy, fruity, floral notes.

Taste: Bready, coarse-grain maltiness with sweetness hinting at a bit of light caramel as well as a drizzling of basic simple syrup. Next, flavors from both the Ommegang house yeast and American-Slovenian hop mix struggle out competing complexities, giving tastes of pears, lemon peel, acidic grapefruit juice, ground white pepper, cloves, dried herbs, day-old dough, and light underlying cellar-like funk. A generous, though not overblown bitterness is present. Some alcohol warmth bordering the dry, zestful finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-high carbonation. Its got that smooth and sticky yet also fizzing on the tongue thing going on.

Overall: A nice Belgian-inspired beer where the hops and yeast steal the show. The alcohol is up there, though not entirely disproportionate. Still, I appreciate the 12-ounce portion, instead of having to drain an entire bomber bottle.

Light golden beer with a slight amber tint.  Billowy head abounds.  And keeps abounding.  Needs multiple pours to get it in the glass.

Sweet and spicy scents with a solid yeast presence and a slight herbal hop aroma.  Good and intriguing.  Smells a bit like a tripel.

Light but full flavor.  Doughy bread, pears, white grapes, and earthy/herbal hops.  Leaves a nice dry and tangy finish.

Translucent gold, bubbly white head, Medium body, medium-high co2.

Aroma: fruity belgian yeast.

Taste: fruity belgian yeast, slightly harsh american aroma hops.
Dark brown, dry hopped "Belgian-style" pale ale. Its a little too stringent and some say has too much of a licorice taste. Its okay, but not my favorite.

Poured a golden color with a big head that dissipated fairly quick.  Aroma was of some hops and grainy/grassy.  Just a tad sweet notes on the nose.   Fairly weak aroma.  Taste is light bitter and light sweetness.  Lighter bodied, slick texture, fizzy carbonation.   I was wanting more of the belgium yeast flavor and not getting it.  Tasted more grainy/grassy that I preferred.  Maybe this bottle wasnt as fresh?

Cloudy, amber/gold appearance with a large, dense, long lasting white head and very good lacing.  Yeast up first in the aroma, with spicy hops close behind.  Citrus hop notes on the tip of the tongue turn a little spicier near the finish.  More soft fruit in the dry aftertaste.  Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel with a decent amount of complexity.
Pours a golden honey with a little white head. A nice floral and yeast aroma. Malty up front followed by a citrus hop burst. A well brewed drainable beer.

On tap: pours a clear deep golden amber with a large pillowy white head.  Has a lightly sweet pale malty nose with some floral hoppiness and yeasty esters. Starts with a light malty sweetness with good bittering hop balance before a clean bittersweet resiny finish. A nice and drinkable brew.

Serving: Draft at Fireworks.  It pour a hazy light gold color with a large, meringue head. The nose is very floral with perfume notes.  The flavor has nice yeast notes with florals and a bit of dough.  Light in body with lots of aggressive carbonation leading to a dry finish.  A very nice session brew.

Picked up at State Line Liquors. Poured into a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

Initial pour brings a murky apricot-orange color with a bit of darker orange around the edges. A pretty hard pour brought out a three-finger head that was quite rough and tumbly; really rocky. Single finger persists throughout. Great sticky lacing all over the glass. Big and soapy bubbles.

Initial whiff brings some nice notes of peach and light tropical fruits as well as a bit of light pepper. A bit of very light floral hops comes through as well. Some very mild earthy must in there as well. The taste is some light stone fruits as well as a bit of must and spice. Body is a bit light with low-to-moderate carbonation levels. Glad to have finally gotten ahold of this, but not my favorite.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

20110411  12oz bottle from State Line.  Cloudy, yeast-speckled, glowing golden, with creamy, even, lasting white head that sheets the glass.  Aroma is grassy/straw yeast, light tropical fruit salad hoppiness, sweet tea-cracker malts, wee resinous hints.  Nice, refined if slightly plain, refreshing, creamy-soft body.  Very much enjoyed this one.

Nice to see this in smaller (affordable) bottles.  Pours cloudy golden with lovely white head and nice lacing as it goes down.  Nose of floral and bitter hops, Belgian yeast.  A bit of citrus and grass.  Tastes similar, but very bitter and dry.
(Draught) clear with a ring of white bubbles. Nose of Belgian yeast, raisin, candi sugar. Taste of florals, sweet candi sugar, Belgian yeast. Dry and watery with a lightly bitter finish.

I had this on tap at the Map Room into a pint glass. Murky yeasty gold with a nice white head, good retention and lacing. The aroma is nice with light hops, taste has the hops a bit stronger but easy to drink. Nice easy to drink balanced ale but I wouldnt go out of the way to drink it.

Enjoyed with friends from tap, Spring Bar Los Angeles. Small head tops this light golden brew. Aromas of pine nuts, Belgian yeast orange peels and  hops. Tastes refreshing and bright. An unique  marriage of Belgian style ale with an I P A. Nicely done. I would recommend Urthel Hop it as well.

12oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a bright, clear gold with a thick, rocky, white head and great lacing. aroma is damn nice with fresh orange peels, apricots, and pear nectar with notes of belgian yeast, florals, and hints of nutmeg. flavor is very tasty as well with a smooth balance of bitter citrus and sweet tropical fruit hop notes with dry, belgian yeast, coriander, clove, and a bit of cinnamon on the finish. palate is crisp, dry, and light in the mouth with strong carbonation and a hoppy finish. overall, a damn nice belgian pale.

22oz bottle: pours hazy pale golden with a thick off white head. Notes of mango, apple juice, Belgian yeast, sweet malts, earthy hops from the distinctive dry hopping. Really pleasant blend of cedar hops and esters. Nice balance and dry finish. Id have another.

Aroma: citrus, floral
Appearance hazy, orange, white foam
Taste: medium sweetness
Palate: medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish,

very nice pale ale of the American variety in terms of hop profile. sweet with an Earthy Belgian style malt and spice character of coriander and bit of banana. yeasty mouthfeel and altogeather a success. nice zesty carbonation rounded to balance with the competing flavors that are also well balanced.
Nice hoppiness for the style, though it is smooth and malty. A very good seasonal form Ommegang.

Pours a clear orange with a big, fluffy, white head. Very good lacing. Aroma of Belgian yeast, spices, hops, citrus, and a tiny bit of honey. Flavor is moderately sweet and highly bitter. Good body but perhaps a bit too hoppy.

Pours hazy orange with white head, aroma has notes of belgian spice, bubblegum and banana, complimented by notes of fruity hops.  Taste is a nice balance between fruity esters, spicy and earthy belgian yeast, and some fruity hops.  Nice balanced, slightly bitter.

Large head that gave way to an impressive brew.  Citrus is everywhere, a bit of a soapy splash at first taste as well.  Color is solid pale ale yet gives ways to an avenue that explores the belgian impications.  Love the dry hopping in this one as the pallate just beckons for another stab at this masterful brew.  There are some earthy undertones on this one and the organic fresh feel is prevalent, but this is such a great brew.  Another gem here from a great brewery.

Tap. Fluffy white head on a hazy marigold body. Floral aromas, hint of vanilla, some white grapes, and a slight fruity sourness.  Taste has a bit more of a sharpness to it thats almost a little tart along with some zesty hop presence.  Light grapes continue, and very crisp overall. Lighter body with snappy carbonation.  Lovely stuff.
Pours a hazy orange with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is spicy and citrus.  Taste is well balanced between spicy yeast, malt and hops.  Very refreshing, would drink again.

Bottle courtesy of James on 10/22/2010. Slightly hazy orange body with a small creamy off-white head. Fruity aroma with belgian spice. Spicy flavor with light caramel and fruit. Medium body with moderately high carbonation.

From tap at Cheers, Boston. Pours cloudy dark orange with a small white head. Aroma is spiced phenolic, coriander and slight spiced. Solid hoppy flavoured. Slight spiced and dry bitter hoppy. Bitter, slight spiced and dry fruity finish.

On tap at Jacs - Pours hazy copper with a nice off-white head. Smells of mango and pineapple, with nice sweetness, yeast, and herbal hops. Taste is sweet malt, honey, flowery hops, with a nice grassy finish. Usually put off by too much grassiness, but they dial it down nicely. Fairly syrupy, with decent carbonation. Id drink this any day.

Aroma: Citrus--grapefruit, maybe?--hops, with hints of floral.
Appearance: Sparking gold with thick, white head.
Taste: Complex--Medium sweetness balanced with medium bitterness, light sourness and a hint of salt in the finish.
Palate: Medium body, lively carbonation, decent flavorful finish
Overall: Very beautiful beer.  This is elegant with a lot of depth. Not my ideal, but a beer that certainly caught my attention.
750 thanks to Seth. Orange. Zest. Yeasty. Very flavorful. Enjoyed this one.

Pours golden / amber with a large off-white head.  The aroma has lightly toasted malt, fruity Belgian yeast, nectarines, spicy hops and it is very yeast heavy and pleasant.  Medium body with a ton of sharp carbonation.  The flavor begins with much of the aroma traits with less fruitiness, more hops (pine & spice) and some nuttiness.  The finish is clean and hoppy with a touch more yeastiness.  Nice beer.
12oz bottle included in an Ommegang mix pack. Another good belgian ale style offering from Ommegang though I found this one to be less satisfying than their others that I have tried.
Bottle in Baltimore.  Plenty of foamy head and lacing, lemon golden, some must and one of the better efforts to incorporate hops, which for me just doesnt fit too the belgian style

Pours a golden amber with medium head that sticks around. Aroma of spicy Belgian yeast and tropical fruits. Taste is a mix of citrus/tropical fruit and spicy phenols with a bit of band-aid. Malts are mostly in the background, but its built well. Moderate bitterness. Dry finish. Very nice and drinkable. Balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 It pours hazy gold with a foamy beige head that laces nicely. The aroma is quite fruity, with some banana and spice from the Belgian yeast, along with some citrus and lemon from the hops and sweet candy sugar. It has a light sweetness from the malt up front, but is fairly dry in the middle and on the finish. Some more spice on the palate along with some caramel and more fruit. Hops really shine on the finish, dry with a light bitterness and more citrus. Great job of blending the hoppiness of a pale ale with the classic fruity Belgian yeast. Complex and delicious.

Pours light golden color almost of a lager.  Head is completely white and tasteless, and plenty of it.  Lots of bubbles in this one, almost like champagne.  Smells of earthy hops.  Taste is light which is reflective of the color.  Not as may fruity notes as I would have liked.  The aftertaste that lingers is strong and hoppy.  I would probably be more into this beer if it was the summertime.

A big gushing head that is white with a gold tint.  It fades slowly.  The beer is hazy orange with plenty of yeast sediment floating.  An aroma of fruit and yeast.  Flavor is nice with Belgian yeast and citrus fruit everywhere.  The hops are understated and do nothing but enhance.  They add more fruit, soft bitterness, and a bit of spice.  This is a very nice beer.  It is very easy to drink and the ABV is reasonable enough to enjoy  plenty of it.

Pours a cloudy, amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of lemon, citrus hops, yeast, and some grapefruit.  Light mouthful with the fruits right away.  Some nice bitterness from the citrus and pine hops.  Not my favorite from Ommegang but still pretty good.

Caged and corked, 750ml bottle.  Bottled on 09.21.2010, one month to the day older than unclemattiejr.  Golden orange color.   Huge Froth of a head.  It resembles a newborn albinos scrotum.  Bright white and wrinkled.  Next is the aroma.  Wonderous floral bouquet.  Herbal and citrus under big florals.    The florals are so overwhelming.  Flavor is a pure, clean malt.  All followed by a resin, medicinal, floral, hop heaven character that again takes the marquee.  Finishes very smooth,  a mellow dry malt,  lots of aromatic hops.  Couldnt ask for a better beer.  So close to perfect, I feel guilty for not sharing this bottle just for the taste alone.  

10,5,9,4,18

(draft @ Tap and Mallet - Rochester, NY) Clear amber pour with a fizzy white head. Bitter and dry hop aroma with just the lightest touch of yeast and spice. Flavor is bitter hops at the start that moves to a bitter spice and yeast middle nearing the finish. Bitter and lingering aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 On tap at Valhalla.  Do you want something that tastes citrusy, nutty, hoppy, with a dash of cheese too?  This might do it. More APA than Belgian, but the unusual combination (due to the Belgian yeast?) works out nicely.  Not heavy, and with a dry finish.  Another good release out of Cooperstown.

First beer of the day before the Dec BA Tasting @ The Gingerman-Houston .. . Pours a deep honey hazy yellow .. . great big sturdy white foam, lacing is all over the place .. . Light doses of bitterness, floral, hay, and light zest .. . would have on tap again .. .  Oh, cmon, were like the sons you never had.   If you were my son, Mac, I wouldve smothered you by now.  Smothered me in gravy you big dirty man.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2011 Found what may have been the last bottle in the area of this last weekend at Lone Star Beverages in Carrollton. Poured into a Duvel tulip.
Average BPA colour, light gold with some cloudiness. Decent head with some lacing.
Aroma is a bit above average-belgian yeast funkiness and some nice hops. 
Above average flavor as well. Some lemon zest and hop spicyness. 
**UPDATE** Ive since had this on tap as well and it was slightly better on draught

Tap. Rating #205. Dark gold with a small, clingy white head.  Very nice hop aroma, light pineyness and very floral and fragrant. Dry, hoppy and a bit fruity from the belgian yeast and it all blends together quite well, real nice drinker.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Pours a hazy burnt orange with gold highlights and a fluffy, bubbly white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, orange, dust, sourdough bread, herbs, hay, grass and pepper.  Flavor of toast, caramel, dust, pepper, citrus, pine and maybe mushrooms.  Substantially bitter in the finish with pepper, citrus, and burnt bread crust mingling with plenty of yeast funk.  Light-medium bodied, fluffy texture befitting the appearance and high carbonation.  No heat presence.  Good offering, nice yeast presence but the "hoppy, pale Belgian style" fad can only go so far and its tough for me to look forward to these beers, much less LOVE them.
On tap at Armsby Abbey -  Big Belgian triple style aftertaste with hints of florality throughout.

Hazy orange color. Aroma is very perfumy, almost medicinal. A ton of lemon and quite funky. Wicked nose, but unique enough that I cant stop smelling it. Flavor contains earthy notes, hay, grassy, dry, herbal bitterness.
Bottle. Golden hazy pour with some white head. Apple, banana, clove, some sweet malt, aroma. Sweet fruit, some light citrus, a touch of warming on the finish.

Ive had this on-tap a few times-but I guess I havent reviewed yet. I picked up a great Ommegang gift set with 3 750s and the official Ommegang glassware! SO 750 ml bottle poured into my Ommegang glass.

A-Body is a uniformly translucent golden yellow hue. Pours with a 3 finger + foamy white head. Head slowly fades to 1 finger and leaves LOTS and LOTS of lacing behind in the glass. Translucency is minimum.

S- Nose is somewhat mild but offers a profile typical and good for the style. Belgian candi sugar, mild soft, floral hops, lemon, and sweet bready yeast.

T- Flavor is very good-stronger and more balanced than the nose. Upfront is a mild lemon and tropical fruit flavor with a sweet backbone. Spiciness and breadiness slowly come through just before the finish and intensify. Floral hops accent the finish. What lingers is a touch of floral hops and a moderate amount of peppery spice as well as a hint of sugar and citrus.

M- High carbonation and lightweight drinkable body. Body is slightly juicy.

D- This is a very good BPA overall. Its drinkable, almost sessionable, and full of flavor. Another fantastic brew by Ommegang-one of my favorite breweries.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-26-2010 02:55:41
pours a hazy gold with a thick white head. very effervescent.  pleasant aroma of grapefruit.  nice citrus taste complemented by mild hops.  refreshing...would make a great spring/summer beer.

Pour is a hazy copper with an average white head.  Aroma is yeasty, pils malt and spicy hops.  Flavor is dry malts with a nice hop in the backround and a fresh fruit burst toward the end.  Of all the Belgian pale ales\ipas ive had this year this is probaby one of the best.  Very flavorful and fresh.

2010-12-28. Hazy golden orange body with a modest white head. Aroma is lightly sweet and yeasty, mild pale malt. Flavour has a lightly yeasty sweet malt core with a modest bitterness throughout. Smooth average plus palate. Enjoyable and pretty straightforward. Tap at Coles, Buffalo

[3525-20101228] Tap. Mild wheaty fruit aroma. Hazy, light brown orange body with a quick foamy off-white head. Banana wheat flavour is rough around the edges with mild petrol leaf notes. Medium body is rough. Fair.
(@ Coles, Buffalo, NY)

The aroma is caramel, fruit, and characteristic peppery belgian yeats.  The appearance is a nice relativelt clear gold/amber, big white head.  The flavor is spicy/peepery, caramel, fruit.  The beer is on the thin side of medium body.  The finish is spicy, pepper, light pine hops.  Decnt, refreshing.  Nice take on the always service-able pale ale.
Great beer.  Cant find anything to give a -point to.  Citrusy, wheat, but you will never know it.  Great color, wonderful head, lacing. Smell, flavor, and feel.  I couldnt ask for anything better.
Draft. Amber beer with a nice cream colored head. Yeast and light estery aroma. Yeast and light spice flavor with light esters. Medium bodied. Light spice and yeast lingers with light malt.

Pour is relatively opaque and bright yellow with a rocky lacy off white head...hmmmm...Im trying to quiet my mind because this beer looks a little like Matilda, or....Orval...I know Ive had this before but cant recall it at all...smell is lightly fruity and citrusy with hops being the predominant note...taset is dry and hoppy...grapefruit and estery Belgian yeast dominate the flavor...I had hoped for an Orval clone...but alas...some nice malty flavors (not sweet, just malt) and then a nice dry finish....good.

Draft at Hopleaf.  Hazy golden tan.  Thick, creamy white head.  Hoppy, astringently sweet Belgian yeast aroma.  Creamy and rather surprisingly malt centered, considering the aroma.  Yeasty, quite a nice balanced BPA.  Sweet, almost nutty at times, almost Tripel-like at others.  Well done.
Pours a nice cloudy golden color. It pours with a creamy effervescent  head. Has a nice floral, citrus taste with a strong hop aftertaste.

Ommegang Brewery--BPA--Belgian-style Pale Ale--Dry Hopped--Limited Edition--2010 25.4 oz. Bottle.  6.20% ABV. 55 IBUs?  (3.75 / 5.0)  New Style?  IPA BPA CDA?  Huge pillowy white foam lace head.  Big Bottle Conditioned Sediment.  Cloudy fizzy bright orange color.  Aromatic Cascade dry hop mild Belgian ester front.  Thin textured dry crisp zesty too fizzy Belgian fruit mild citrus refreshing Pale malt body.  Balanced hop spice citrus end.	Sampled 12/24/2010.  Purchased for $7.99 @ Whole Foods--Magnolia, Seattle on 4/21/2010.

Bottle.

A - Light, crisp golden orange color with a large, foamy, light, sticky, fluffy and rocky, white head. Really good retention that sticks around for a long time and leaves a nice layer of lace.

S - Strong Belgian yeast characteristics. A touch of spiciness and lemon citrus. Subsequent whiffs get more American hop aromas on the nose. Some tropical fruit with pineapple, mango, tangerine, and apricot. Also a nice amount of ripe golden fruit. Just a little bit of a musty finish on the nose.

T - Really nice combination of Belgian yeast and American hops. Starts with a big kick of tropical fruit and golden fruit. Pineapple, grapefruit, tangerine, apricot, peach, and others all present coming in and out. Slightly sweet flavor but a faint bitter bite. Then the spicy Belgian yeast flavors come into play. Faint candi sugar and dry bready flavors in the background.

M - Lighter side of medium body with average carbonation. Nice sprizty feel, but just a little too thin.

D - Really enjoyed drinking this. It went down easy with the nice mix of Belgian yeast and spiced characteristics and the American hops bringing a fruity aspect. Sweet and spice nicely balanced.

Notes: I really enjoyed this beer. Sweet, fruity flavors present, but the spice really cuts it and provides a nice contrast. Really zesty and refreshing to drink.

bottle - Pours hazy golden-orange with a big, lasting head that laces well.  It smells of lightly spicy Belgian yeast and hops with a little citrus.  The flavor is malty up front with yeasty, citrusy tones and ample hops that soon take over.  The hops contribute to a fairly dry finish.  This medium bodied brew is lively on the palate and good though definitely not my favorite from this excellent brewery.

From Tap:
 Clear orange pour with BIG WHITE HEAD, disappates rather slow and leaves nice lacing. Nose is candy malt and orange-y citrus.
sweet light malt and citrus middle Light body.
 Surprisingly dry clean finish.
Fruity and hoppy, light golden colored.  A little sweet. Not bad, but Belgian IPA is not one of my favorite styles.
Golden yellow-orange, huge white foam.  Aroma is alcohol and pear.  Taste is sweet malt, spicy alcohol, sweet finish.  I like it but it borders on non-descript.

Gold pour with a thick foamy white head.
aroma is citrusy and slightly floral. Some apricot and pear fruitiness. Light earthiness. 
Flavour has earthy mown hay, fruitiness is apple, unripe peach/apricot.  some biscuity malt.  some grapefruit in the finish.
very drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours an orange body with a white head and good retention.  Crackers with light and spicy yeast toned notes.  A light fruit character with prickly carbonation.  Apple, citrus, and fruit toned esters with a mild earth.  Decent.

Pours a thick foamy yeasty head. Smells of citrus and flowery spices. Light palate, almost tastes like a saison, but a little fuller. This is very easy to drink. Not my favorite from Ommegang, but Id try it again.

Appearance: straw under a nice white head which fades into a soft blanket while lace slowly crawls up the side of my glass. Steady stream of bubbles seeing as she was draft.

Nose: bright with tons of dry tropical fruits up front. Coriander, grains of paradise, and white pepper abound, tickling my nose with each snuff. Dry husked grains underneath; grape nuts. An overall zesty tropical fruity essence with a touch of green.

Palate: sweet in the middle with a mild front. Pineapple, guava, and mango skins for bitter-sweet tropical essence. Green of palm and aloe underneath. The palate dries slowly, lingering with the bitterness of fruit skins and dry baled hay. Spice lingers in the back and in my breath. As she warms white grapefruit joins the tropical fray, the rind especially.

Final Thoughts: not too shabby for a Belgian that is not quite a Belgian and not quite a pale ale. Would be great with some delicate white fish cooked slowly over the grill with just some simple lemon juice and pepper for seasoning. Yum!

Pours hazy gold with a fluffy head. The smell is that of ripe fruit, pepper, and a touch of funk. There is a bit more funk in the flavor than the smell along with some orange zest and ripe banana. Extreme carbonation creates a drying effect. Pretty good.

Clear dull yellow pour with billowing pillowy white head.  Sweet and orange zest.  Belgian yeasty large carbonation.
Sweet with a dryish finish. Not a big fan.

750ml bottle in a shaker.  Pours golden and cloudy with a white head.  Aroma of Belgian spicy yeast with a strong hops note for a Belgian style beer.  I wish more Belgian beers had this strong of a hopping.  Definitely worth trying.

Pours golden with a very soft, delicate white head. The aroma has overripe fruit and a little grain. The flavor is very spicy (much more so than the aroma) with strong peppery notes, coriander, orange, and a strong hoppy finish. Much fuller bodied than expected, and leaves nice lacing in the glass.
Poured a hazy orange with a wispy head, Nose of generic hops and a very thin palate. No "weight" to this one.
Draught from W front, a nice amber pour, a decent head, pleasantly mild hops.  well done.

huge rocky fluffy white head... Hazy golden w some sediment.... Aroma of fruits, belgian yeast, grassy hops... Flavor is fruity almost a touch sour with grassy hops... A little thinner than expected... good flavor for a belgian pale, certainly one of the better of these relatively new beers....

From a corked and caged 750ml.  Pours a hazy yellow with a bunch of head and mild to moderate lacing.  Aroma of grass, Belgian flavor, flour, and citrus fruit.  Mouthfeel is pretty light and a tad bit dry.  Yeast builds it up a bit but not too much... about right for a pale ale.  Taste is dead on for the style... a Belgian Pale ale.  Belgian taste is present along with some light hops, funk and barely a touch of alcohol.  This is fairly similar to Ommegangs Hennepin, also an excellent beer.  If you have a buddy youd like to get into Belgians, this is the perfect gateway drug.  A really good beer that MUST make its way into 12 oz 6 packs!!!!!!!

On tap at the Flying Saucer in Houston. A very clear orange-gold color with a white foamy head that has great retention. Citrus tones lead in the aroma, with a bit of spice in the background. The flavor starts with tangerine-flavor hops and a medium level of lemon-like bitterness, along with light malt in the background. A little bit of Belgian yeast spice throughout and especially in the finish. Nice smooth palate. A balanced and well-crafted brew, quite easy to drink.
nice aroma of citrus and yeast with some subtle spices.  Body is medium with strong carbonation.  taste is very dry with notes of lemon and yeast.  finish is nicely hoppy.

Bottle (pkg on 1/19/10, best by 1/2012): pour is a cloudy orange with a thin, wispy white head, aroma of hops and citrus, taste is mildly hoppy, citrus, thin bodied with plenty of carbonation. Very nice ale.

Tap @ Wits End.  This poured a clear amber body with a respectable head. The aroma was citrusy with other light fruit and a soft floral character. The flavor adds more orange and a subtle spiciness. A decent enough ale worth repeating, but nothing overly special.

On tap at the Gingerman Fort Worth.  Light orange pour with a bubbly white head.  Aroma is banana, floral, lemon, and grass.  Taste is dry fruit, more floral esters, grain, hops sit nicely.  Good finish.

Beautiful golden brown pour with a two finger white head. A little lacing, some head left over when the last drop was consumed.  Love the smell of this beer. Belgian all the way with the hops hiding beneath.  Hoppy with a very light aftertaste. I get a hint of what I characterize as classical Belgian. I was looking for a little more of a lingering taste though. Definitely a thirst quencher.  This is much lighter than I expected, but the ABV will pack a punch after a few. For one of the last hot days of the summer, this was a good choice.

Tap at gman fw poured into my Ommegang BPA lager glass. Appearance is a rusted orange with a bubbly white head. Aroma is a yeasty nose with spicy citrus. Hops are tasted first off with some hop bitterness to accompany. Belgian yeast and light fruit are not felt until the aftertaste. Floral on the tail end. Interesting.

I really liked this one. Mellow and refreshing. It has a light amber appearance with a big white head. The aroma was orange and grapefruit and quite wonderful. The flavor was different though with a big malty character up front followed by the hop bitters. A touch of the Belgian sweetness comes through at the very end. Delightful after taste has the hops lingering on the tongue.

Draught muddy pig 2010 Belgian beer fest. Nice hop nose. No visible carbonation but nice lace. Bartender told me this is essentially a Lagunitas pale with Belgian yeast. Very nice sessionable pale that is unique due to the Belgian qualities.

Pours hazy light amber with a rocky, big white head that settled eventually into a smooth cap that lasted the whole drink (bodys color got darker on the 3rd glassfull, due to the yeast.  Very cloudy, more of an orange hue).  Lots of visible carbonation floating up within the glass. Oh, the aromas!  Im getting a bouquet of pear and red apple, mixed with classic Belgian yeast and grassy hops, with a whiff of malt.  Tastes are all the same as the nose, which is a compliment and a delight.  Its a classic yet-boundary pushing Pale Ale in that it has a robust bitter finish behind the dry hopped grassy/citrusy palate, balanced nicely with a hint of fruity malts.  Yet its also a fantastic Belgian ale, in that the Yeast is full and flavorful, while never dominating, allowing the fruity malt/hop combo to do its sweet thang.  Its essentially 2 styles in 1 beer, and its incredibly well made.
Bottle:  Poured a cloudy gold with a white head.  The aroma was hops, pale malts, and yeast.  The flavor was well balanced, hops and yeast, some orange and bread.  Overall, a really well made beer.
A seasonal draft at BXL Cafe, NYC.  Another hit for Brewery Ommegang.  Very enjoyable with rich fruit and hop/malt aroma.  More hoppy than a traditional Belgian ale with lasting finish.

Pours a hazy yellow into the glass with a nice white head.  Aroma is spicy and citrusy with some cereal like grain coming through.  The flavor of this beer is outstanding.  Lots of orange citrus notes and belgian spice.  Great body with a nice high carbonation level.  Mmm.

Rich amber color with an active, white head. Delicious, full-grain malt aroma. Cascade hios round out the package. Mild belgian yeast flavor thats full, delicious, but not heavy. Too delicious to tolerate. The gk avor bounces back and forth between the yeasty belgian character that we all know and love and the pale american malt that is equally enjoyable. It seems that every other sip you have two beers in one glass.  Belgian and bitter finish. Cheers!

Pours a yellow color with a slight orange tint. Creamy yet soapy white head. Notes of grass, crystalized pineapple, sweat, clover, and citrus. Mouthfeel on the watery side. Doesnt really feel like a traditional begin ale (very low carbonation, and no real funk) but a solid well made beer Albeit understated.

Bottle. Poured orange with a creamy white head that had a thin layer lasting and left light lace. Aroma of banana and spice. The flavor had spices with a grain and hop backing. Medium body and a spice aftertaste.

On tap at the Bronx Ale House, NY. Pours a golden body with a foam-white head. The aroma is light hops and yeast. Flavor is hoppy, very bready with a slight yeast flavor toward the end; has a little tingle of citrus as well. Very light carbonation.

The Dan Journal #401. Tasted 9/6/10. 750ml Cork and Cage bottle. Layer of white head. Aromas of candy citrus and mild grapefruit. Full bodied with a bright effervescence. Crisp and bitter palate. Tangy and tart flavors. Solid!

750 ml. Gold body with orange highlights, hazy. Frothy, white head, mostly diminishing. Aroma of toasted grain, hay, flowers, perfume, citrus, orange and earthiness with a hint of mustiness. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. The finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter and lightly acidic. Medium body, creamy texture and fizzy carbonation. Pleasant  aroma, but a disappointing flavor  especially a strong perfume note in the finish. Slight sour twang in the finish, too, along with the soapiness. Overly fizzy mouthfeel.
Nice beer but I had high expectations and was let down as bit.   Would definitely drink again but wouldnt seek it out.

On tap, Devils Den.  Pours a slightly hazy gold body with a small wispy white head.  The nose is nicely hoppy with light pale malts and a nice belgian yeast note.  The flavor is bright, hoppy, nicely yeasty with a great bready maltiness.  A slight orange/citrus note on the finish.  Mouthfeel is light and airy with great lively fizzy carbonation.  Overall, a really nice take on the style.  Very light, airy, and refreshing.

Thanks for sharing, bro!  Pours a lightly cloudy golden color with a medium white soapy head.  Aroma is like a Saison - light citrus, light spice.  Tastes very much like a Saison.  Refreshing and delish.

pours from a 750 ml bottle as a pale yellow, with a substantial off white head.  This has aromas of pine, citrus, banana....really nice.  The beer tastes even better, as the dry hopping really provides a nice hoppy balance to this beer.  I really like the sweet Belgian yeast balanced against the American hops.  This is a VERY good beer and one I wish was available regularly.
A big bottle.  Nice citrus-y aroma with a cloudy orange color.  Nice smooth mouthfeel with a mellow flavor with just the right balance of everything.  Not too hoppy at all.  Just right.

Pours a hazy straw color with thick, fluffy, white head.  Aroma is of Belgian yeast, some light funk, and citrus hops.   Taste is of strong Belgian funky yeasts with intertwined citrus hop profile.  Well balanced and extremely tasty.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 750ml bottle into a tulip glass. There is a short description of the beer on the label as well as its ABV with is 6.2%.

Appearance: The body is hazy and has an orange/gold colored body with a creamy light beige head. Its head is tall and frothy which makes nice spotty and slippery lace on the glass. As I slowly drink the head slowly settles to thin cap of foam that lasts to the last sip.

Smell: In the nose I pick up sweet fruity and funky yeast with some bready maltiness and light floral/citrusy and spicy hops.

Taste/Palate: On the tongue there is a similar mix of what was picked up in the aroma. I get notes of fresh peaches, white grapes, dried apricots, and funky/doughy yeast. This has a sweet character that begins to dry out as some of the hops move in and adds there mild bitterness and floral, citrusy grapefruit flavor. 

Notes: I am glad to see some more brews being bottled from Ommegang even if they are only limited releases. I really liked the BPA and hope it will become a yearly release.

Bottle. Light amber. Thin head. Soapy hop scent. Finish is a little soapy but also fishy. Flavour is a light yeasty Belgian inspired Pale Ale. I guess they hit their target. I find the yeast weighs too heavy on the delicate pale ale creating the worlds first "dry chalked beer" with a hint of lemon.
Copper pour with creamy white head and lace. Light earthy hops and brown sugar. Semi sweet caramel malt, light spicey, a hint of brown sugar. A tad thin with a bit off carbonation.

Draft at the Three Penny Taproom - Pours a dark golden amber in color with a thick white head.  Aroma is heavy with Belgian yeast and citrus hops.  Flavor was a bit more complex... still the Belgian yeast and citrus hops, but add a deeper citrus flavor along with some honey and biscuit malt.  It works for me... I like it...

750 ml bottle cork and caged purchased at Canals Hainesport. Poured a hazy straw edged sunset burnt orange body under a slightly foamy off white head. Aroma of yeast, tropical fruit, toast, nutts, slight honey and a hint off toffee flavored candle wax. Medium to lighter bodied with soft carbonation. Flavors of honey, wax, toffee, biscuit, grains, yeast, bitter fruit and seltzer. Interesting and then some.
Not one of my favorites.  To strong on the Belgian side for me.  But it was what I expected from a Belgian Brewery.  If you like the Belgian beers this is for you.

750 ml bottle

The bar was set kind of high for this beer which is why it may have fallen short. Regardless I could not get into it all that much despite an interesting mixture of flavors and texture. That wont stop me from keeping up with Ommegang as they crank out new experiments like the Zuur and a Scottish ale however. Just make sure to get a fresh bottle and you should be fine.

Aroma / Appearance - Carbonated and bronze the appearance did not give away anything other than the expected. A rich white head was so intense it took a few minutes for the beer to actually settle to a drinkable level. Grapefruit, orange rinds, melons, and strands of cotton candy give it a fruity playful tone.

Flavor / Palate - The fluid mouthfeel is light with little residual impact on either the tongue or throat. Fading almost like the cotton candy it tastes like the delicacy is a minor turnoff. I was not expecting a huge in your face statement. It is nice though for the finish to last more than two seconds. I cant complain about the cost though - at $5.99 this was very much in the affordable "check it out" price bracket.

Pours a clear light golden color with an off-white head and many tiny bubbles racing toward the surface.  The head is made of fairly tiny bubbles, but craters nicely.  This beer has a nice citrus aroma with hints of sweet honey.  The flavor is light belgian and is maltier than I would have thought based on the aroma.  This beer is easy drinking, relatively light flavored and feels fairly crisp in the mouth.  This is a fairly good belgian styled ale.

Corked bottle and served in my Ommegang tulip: Slightly hazy golden hue topped by a fluffy white head which left spotty lacework upon the glass. The aroma has notes of citric PNW as well as milder herbal noble hops, lots of fruity esters (mango, pineapple, grapefruit, pear), moderately hop spiced with pepper and clove, pale pils and two-row malts, and a dusty yeast vapour. The taste is moderately reserved which is a good thing as too many of these hoppy Belgian Ales I have had of late are too hop forward and honestly clash... that is NOT an issue with the BPA. The hops work very well with the malt bill providing a approachable balance yet still interesting complexity that hits the spot. The moderate fruity component and finishing hop spice tones add to the palate. Only the slight metallic undertone caused me concern. The mouth feel is lively but there is a growing chalkiness that I find annoying after awhile.  Overall I found this to be a solid offering that I would gladly try again. I think Ommegangs history and respect to the Belgian styled ales kept them grounded to what this beer should be, not overly hopped to the point of becoming an IPA and for that I am happy. If only this brew was cleaner and less chalky/metallic then this would be a higher level of happiness.

Golden pour floating a big robust fluffy white head.  Aromas of cirusy hops and phenolic Begian yeast esters.  In this case, "phenolic" is not meant as a knock...I liked the strong Belgian yeasty profile...both in the nose and in the flavor.   Citrus notes throughout...orange and lemon, along with some light floral hoppiness as well.   Really light and refreshing on this hot summer night.

On tap at Ginger Man.  Pours a cloudy straw yellow with a big frothy white head.  Aroma is citrus, banana, hop and yeast.   Taste is a big mouthfeel and body.  Hop flavour is very full and is nicely offset by the citrus and belgian yeast.  Really well balanced beer.  Ive had a couple of other "belgian-ale" and this is probably the best balanced one Ive had so far.  Very good beer.

Pours a hazy yellow with a medium sized white head. Citrusy aroma with banana and clove, very tripel-esque. The flavor is similar, hoppy and smooth. Nice mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Saaz hops on the finish. Very tasty.
Clear golden with a foamy white head.  Good strong bready Belgian yeast, fruit, and citrus aroma and taste with a bright and lively palate.  Quite good.

Had several times now and its a decent addition to Ommengang lineup.  Pours a hazy orange with pretty white lacing head.  Taste is yeasty with spiced malt, pineapple, clove and finishes dry.  doesnt blow me away but something about it draws me back

Pours a cloudy amber color with a tall white head.  Excellent lacing!  Solid carbonation.  Aroma of yeast, a touch of spice, and citrus.  Flavor of yeast, spice, citrus, and a enough hops for a bitter finish.  Nice beer!

Straw colored pour with nice head and minimal lacing.  The aroma was yeasty with a little bit of funk, but with noticeable cascade also present.  The flavor was fruity with hints of pineapple and orange with a moderate level of clove-like spices. Moderate to heavy level of carbonation, which was needed because the malt did leave a bit of stickiness in the mouth.  Overall, I enjoyed this one.  Something a bit different from Ommegang...a welcome addition to their lineup, even if the $10 pricetag might make dissuade me from selecting this one over some of my favorite Belgians.

750mL Bottle. Pours a hazy orange and a white head with large bubbles fading to a sticky lace. Yeasty aroma, a bit musty.  Flavor continues with an earthy hoppiness with a bit of orange and yeasty roll.

Tap at Swift Hibernian Lounge.  Pale golden pour and a creamy white head.  The nose is lovely and bright with a soft clove and a lot of grassiness.  Its got a nice minerally character and a sort of oddly musty flavour.  A bit of clean, crisp Belgian pale malt.  Its plenty dry but despite that it seems to be missing a little something.  Sort of flabby  there is an assertive hoppiness but it doesnt really have the sort of rich spiciness I might expect.  Dry and herbal but not as good as it could be.

On tap a Divisions Ale House. Pours gold with a white head. Fruity apricot like aroma with some spicy beligian notes. The flavor has fruity belgian yeast, apricot, and floral hops. Enjoyable on a hot Chicago day sitting outside.

On tap at Pony bar.  Dry and a bit chalky, Belgian spices and yeast.  Soft and delicate but notes of alcohol.

Pours a cloudy orange with a white head. Some grapefruit hops, belgian yeast, biscuit and a bit of spice.  Nice.
Homebrew fizz , dark gold, spotty retention.  Bread + fruitiness + hoppy elements in the nose.  Palate is rich, pine, hops, bananas and the interesting notes of the yeast.  Very very nice.

pours a semi-cloudy orange-yellow with above average carbonation, a large white head, and good lacing.

smell is of pepper, spice, a touch of hops, some citrus in the back, and some wheat.

taste is slightly dry, banana, yeast, some spice, and fresh hops, ends a little thick, and dry.

Bottle shared by daknole -- thanks!  Pours amber in color with a fluffy tan head.  Smells and tastes predominantly of grapefruit rind, Belgian yeast, and earth.  Not bad.

Almost clear golden color/ frothy white foam. Nice dry hay, dusty pale malt aromas with spicy hops, mild barnyard. medium bodied.  Semi dry house yeast flavor with dusty pale malts, spicy hops, mild clove.
