750mL bottle, purchased at Bottle Barn. Pours a bright, bold, deep honey-copper color; highly effervescent; huge, foamy, fine-bubbled head with just great retention and lacing; a beautiful appearance in the glass, flawless. A fair amount of white pepper, citrus, and zesty minerals in the aroma; has the pepperiness and yeast character of a tripel, a very soft, non-intrusive malt core (lightly biscuity) and a prominent citrus / mineral hop note; very solid, lively aroma, with some hints of grassy, herbaceous notes that fit with the dry hopping; mouthwatering. Medium body, perhaps a touch heavier; lively, effervescent carbonation; no obvious alcohol or astringency, very light creaminess; fluffy, mouth-filling texture; a very well-balanced presentation of white pepper and doughiness (yeast), biscuity and bready notes (malts), and zesty citrus / mineral / herbal qualities from the hops; nothing stands out too prominently, or I should say overly so; the malt core is nicely attenuated and just chewy enough, the CO2 keeps this alive in the mouth, the hop character is quite fresh and enjoyable; a great demonstration of a nicely fine-tuned recipe; anything but sloppy. Lasting finish of biscuity malts, lingering citrus and herbal hops, pepper.

Pours deep gold into a tulip. Bright white head slowly recedes to skim surface. Lemon joy and grapefruit aromas. Sweet lemony yeast upfront turning to clove and grapefruit in the lasting bitter finish.

A big amount of chill haze has formed in this beer since I put it in the fridge two days ago.  A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces almost four-fingers worth of nicely tanned foam.  The head slowly falls with pillowy mounds of froth that leaves a rocky surface on the top fo the foam.  The beer is a murky, light amber color that shows a rich haze and lighter copper hues when held up to the light.  Earthy yeast notes mix with spicy herbal hop aromas followed by citrus hop notes in the first whif of the aroma.  My second waft of the aroma sees me noticing tropical fruit hop notes much more with notes of lychee, floral peach and perhaps a touch of kumquat or tangelo zest.  Earthy, spicy malt character is accentuated by fruity fermentation notes, and spicy phenolics; this last is a touch musty, a hint of medicinal, with some solid, supporting clove aromatics.  The malt becomes more noticeable as my nose adjusts to the hops, toasted whole grain bread aromatics, rye crackers and fresh crushed grain notes all are apparent.  In addition to the hops, there are other fruit notes of pear and perhaps a light melon like character.  The aroma on this is interestingly complex, and I am quite enjoying the interplay of Belgian yeast, American Hops and malt.

Sweet grapefruit hop flavors are noticeable as the beer first hits my tongue.  The beer dries out quite a bit as it rolls across my tongue though; the malt character is overall dry, but the hops accentuate an up front sweetness that just lingers on the palate even in the long finish.  Both the peppery carbonation and the hops provide a biting, bitter note that is found throughout the flavor profile, but especially lingering in the finish.   Touches of pine and a definite herbal edge also linger towards and into the finish of each sip.  The malt contributes a soft dough-like flavor, some toasted cracker notes as well as a rustic, crushed grain character that lingers in the finish.  It is interesting that the fermentation character accentuates a lychee / tropical fruit flavor from the Cascade hops.  The texture of this beer is fizzy from the ample carbonation, but well tamed by a creamy texture; overall this is quite quaffable and certainly light enough to be what I was expecting labeled as a BPA.  Fermentation spice notes of clove (this is actually quite big and mixes quite well with the hop character), woody black pepper and pink ginger play a bigger and bigger role as the beer warms up.

In a world were there are few commercial examples of American hops and Belgian inspired yeast strains (especially under 7%) this is a really nice beer.  I cant see this standing up if a lot more of these get made though.  As it is though, I am thoroughly enjoying this beer.  My biggest complaint is that the malt seems to muddle things a bit; it does add complexity, but seems to get in the way of the crisp hops and interesting yeast character, though it does add extra complexity, which isnt really needed in a beer chock-full hops and yeast character.  This would also be a bit lighter and more refreshing without the extra malt character; and I dont think that would be a bad thing.

Pours bright golden with a well maintained foamy off-white head. Notes of citrus and floral esters, honey, bubble gum, sweet pale malt and toasted malt. Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation. Very nice.

bottle from metzlers in denton tx.  poured gold with a white head that would no give up.  aroma was lemon, fruits, apple,  banana, and maybe some coriander? and cinnamon.  flavor was lemon, banana, fruits, and a touch of vanilla.  medium body with high carbonation.

Bomber. Pours opaque apricot gold, off white head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity. Flavor is hops with dried fruit and some funky yeastiness. Not too yeasty to be overpowering. Fairly refreshing, not totally my thing though.
Bottle - pours a hazy gold with a thick white head.  Aroma of spices, clove, citrus, and some sweet malt.  Good flavor with the belgian yeast and citrus hops blending well.  Good beer.

750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Pours a hazy golden color with a large fluffy lasting off white head.  The aroma is floral and herbal hops, fruity, some yeast and pale malts.  The flavor is dry yeasty, citrus fruits, pale biscuity malts with some herbal hops.  This is a nice beer, but nothing that really jumps out as being standout.

@Tampa Wkly Gathering @OTH on tap-pours a white head that laces and yellow color.  Aroma is clove/peppers-spice, orange/herbal, sweet light malt.  Taste is clove/peppers-spice, orange/lemon/herbal hops, sweet light malt.  Soft carbonation, somewhat dry finish.
Yellow orange with large white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet, and the taste is sweet and creamy with a slightly bitter finish. Tastes like Duvel.

Clear amber with a massive white head and huge carbonation in the body. She definitely gushed a bit...The aroma is predominantly flowery and citrus hop, clove, banana, and dough. The flavor has a bit more malt character than the aroma would suggest- a nice light caramel note makes itself well known. The hop character is quite pleasant- flowery, lemon/orange citrus, and grassy with some doughy yeast and light slice. The palate is medium bodied, highly effervescent, and finished very dry and crisp.

A gusher; poured out as the cork was released. Super carbonated in the glass, with a large frothy white head. Amber colored pour. Aroma holds nice citrus and floral hop character, notably orange and lemon zest. Lots of doughy and spicy Belgian yeast as well. Malt character is pretty subtle. Flavor holds an interesting combination of the sweet and spicy Belgian character, with clove and banana, and citrus and flowery hop. Also a decent caramel malt presence. Palate is medium bodied with a crisp and fairly dry finish. Nice brew overall.

Golden with big, foamy white head / Delicate nose of banana and spice / Medium body, mild malts with good hopping on the fine, bitter finish / Flavors of banana, lemon, grain, and a little spice on the finish.

Draught at the Red.   Glowing orange-copper with a medium white head that collapses in a short time, but leaves a nice layer of foam.   Bright fruity aroma that seems like a nice combination of bright fruity esters and the cascade hops used post-fermentation.   Peach, apricot and mint, almost with some floral touches.   The flavor has a uicy fruit sweetness that dries out pretty well in the finish but lacks much bitterness or alcohol presence.   The malts are on the lighter side with a cake dough and grainy quality.   Medium-light on texture with soft but present carbonation.   Pretty nice stuff overall, and quite drinkable.   This was much better than what I see most people describing from bottled ratings, so Im thinking it came out better in kegged form--maybe the dry hops are really adding something to the aroma that was lost on the bottling line.

750ml, caged and corked bottle. Poured a medium and lightly hazy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of citrus/lemons, floral hops, and breadiness. Tastes of citrus, citrus rinds, floral, and bready. Lively body.

750ml bottle.  Pours increasingly hazy throughout the bottle, downright cloudy at the final glass.  The color is a stratified, glowing, dusky orange-amber, and there is a billowing head of thick, off-white foam that lasts.  Sticky, clumpy swaths of lacing cling hard to the glass.  The aroma is kind of mundane, showing notes of dried bread, biscuit, and dried apricots amidst countering hints of stale tropical fruit and a bit of grass.  Funky, dry, bretty Belgian yeast seems more of an annoyance than a positive contributor.  Likewise, flavors fall flat, with dry, woody, funky brett yeast dulling an otherwise unique tropical hop profile.  The bready, doughy malts are too assertive as well.  On the tongue, a moderate body comes across semi-dry and mostly boring.  Overall, its a decent, drinkable Belgian pale, but Ive had dozens better within this increasingly popular style, and the pricetag is completely unjustified.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is light amber, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (resin), lightly yeasty (basement), with notes of copper, black tea, plastic, and eucalyptus.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Subdued aroma with some mild off notes doesnt really beckon me to drink this.  Flavor balance is oddly sourish/twangy, and kind of bland.  Very little body or mouthfeel.  Dull and rough.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours turbid orangy with huge fluffy white head.  Nose is spicy and yeasty, not a surprise with this style, with some rock sugary funk, hopcitrus, apricotty fruit, and peppery notes.  Tastes assertively hoppy, on the dry side, spicy, yeasty, and with mid palate fruit.  Complex and enjoyable.
Yellow orange with large white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet, and the taste is sweet and creamy with a slightly bitter finish. Tastes like Duvel.

Bronzed straw-yellow. Tight spackle of froth slowly establishes itself with a gentle pour. Banana taffy, bubblegum, apricot jam, pear syrup, melon (muskmelon, cantaloupe), and peppery alcohol line the estery but fairly dull nose. Distant clove, sulfur, and some very faint floral hop suggestions. Relatively alcoholic and very yeasty with notes of pistachio and paint. Watery and flimsy body.  Fluffy carbonation. Fruity and slick with a citrus marmalade hop character and  a contrasting scratch of alcohol, upfront. Hops are somewhat floral, though there is a disharmonious canned-mandarin-orange element, as well. What hoppy brightness is perceptible is unable to thrive beneath the paintlike yeast and off-putting banana taffy which blanket the palate with a filmy residue. Dry crackery malt accents never become more than a mere whisper due to the lack of cleanness. Slight mineralic grit offers short-lived relief from the omnipresence of alcohol and doughy yeast. Hop bitterness, while clean, lies buried beneath the yeastiness. Closes with a vaguely herbal and grassy hop flourish alongside light fusel astringency, cakey malt, unripe banana and honey-drizzled toasted malt. All beer should be clean, and its absolutely mandatory that a Belgian golden be just that. Very displeased with the yeast character and the rampant banana taffy, lack of lively phenolics, to name a few things. About what one would expect from this mediocre-at-best brewery.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 27, 2011 Sampled on draft at Smokin Joes in Pittsburgh PA this beer poured a pale yellow color with a medium sized white head that produced good lacing. The aroma was crisp floral and fruity hops with a tangy sugary undertone. The flavor was yeasty and a bit funky and must with light bitter fruity hops and undertones of sugar, pepper and tangy malts. The finish was medium length dry, musty and fruity hops. Medium body. Reminded me of a hoppy saison. Decent.

Tasted from 750mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy tan orange with a thin beige head.  Hoppy nose with that signature Belgian yeasty smell that always reminds me of lemon and biscuit.  Palate is super mellow with the hops taking a back seat.  Lemon zest, biscuit, black pepper, and light hops flavor round out the palate.  The carbonation is very high with a sticky texture and a rather short finish.  This is an easy drinker that will go great with foods.

On tap at Tribes in Mokena, IL:  This poured a clear amber body with a respectable head.  The aroma was citrusy with other light fruit and a soft floral character.  The flavor adds more orange and a subtle spiciness.  A decent enough ale worth repeating, but nthing special.

The aroma has plenty of malt as well as flowers, herbs, fruit, and spice. It reminds me of a german beer hall. The color is deep gold with a large head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is typical for the style. Overall a fine beer.
slightly fruity aroma. smooth feel with a fantastic look and golden  fields. little hops.

750 ml bottle. Pours a mostly translucent golden amber with a large foamy white head.  Aroma of nice cascade hops, orange, floral, bready malt and light Belgian yeast character.  Flavor again of those cascade hops.  Floral and orange, nice Belgian yeast character and some iced tea notes.

Tap.  Pour is rich looking clear brown with a medium beige head.  Aroma is fruity, roasted malt, light floral, and light spice.  Hops are present but take a back seat to the malts.  Flavor is also quite spicy and fruity with hints of pine hop and belgian yeast.  Nice.

The pour is a hazy honey color with a massive, white, fluffy, rocky head which settles in time to a thin fluffy layer and leaves some soapy lace rings.  The nose is pleasant with estery/dusty yeast, orange peel, mango, some bitter oranges, nice fresh floral tones, maybe a bit of pepper, and hints of pine.  The flavor is similar with subtle biscuit notes, orange and bitter oranges all over, flowers, mild pepper notes, and some dusty yeast.  The palate is nice with a more than medium body, a nearly lively carbonation, and a velvety mouthfeel.  The finish is a bit short but pleasant with floral tones, bitter oranges, biscuits, and light pepper.  Actually a very nice beer from a style which tends not to work well.  The style tends to have the Belgian notes clashing with the hop notes but this was they worked well together.  The subtleties and the orange notes really made the beer.  The beer was incredibly easy to drink and carried a nice balance of Belgian and hoppy notes.  This brewery does great things and this one did not disappoint.

Tap, Malt and Vine.  Hazed golden pour with a lovely thick layer of white foam.  This has a very yeasty aroma of tropical fruit, with some ripe peach and citrus notes.  Reminded me a bit of the aroma of Unibroues yeast, but toned down with a bit more hops.  Tastes of hay, grass, citrus, coriander, and spice.  On the drier side with just a light sweetness to it.  Very easy to drink and nicely balanced between the Cascade hoppiness and the aromatic Belgian yeast.

The aroma of a sweet blonde ale come through in this Belgian pale ale. The hazy orange sunset color has a decent head. The flavor has a bit of funk on this pale ale, but it is Belgian after all. There is not the overpowering hops you expect, but goes down well.

Hazy yellow orange color with a large fluffy white head. Aroma is awesome. Very floral, lots of juicy hops and some faint spice. Taste is a bit herbal and juicy. Nice citrus hops and a nice dryness. Nice lively full body. Very enjoyable, crisp and clean.
Pours gold with a nice, lasting white head.  Smells of grass, hay, dry malt, some citrus.  Tastes of dry malt, peppery, citrus, hay, grassy, funky.  Nice hop forward Belgian ale.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a slight tarnished gold, white head, good lace.  Particularly malty nose but also has a good floral, slightly grassy hop aspect as well.  Flavor is a little sweet, not too bitter.  Has that Belgian blond/pale ale aspect ive seen other places.  Pretty good easy drinking beer, but not done as well as some others Ive seen.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Floral, spicy aroma sweet citrus blossoms with hints of coriander and white pepper.  Pours a slightly hazy blonde with a thick white head.  Citrusy with tropical fruit notes with some sweetness with some grassy notes as well.  Finishes dry with hints of grapefruit.  Nice hop flavor but not overly hoppy and combined with fruitiness of the Belgian yeast makes a very nice beer.
Pours cloudy yellow with a thin head. Aroma- sweet malt, candi sugar, floral. Taste-caramel, sweet, pale malt, hops in the end. Nicely carbonated and medium body.

Bottle.  Pours a lightly hazed gold with a big creamy white head.  Nice soft musk and yeast, soft wheat and a very faint dry hop aroma.  Medium bodied light and gently sweet with a nice amount of wheat and a bit of fruity citrus.  Crisp finish with apple and musk notes.  Pretty tasty.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Hazy amber pour with a tall, thick, frothy white head. Bubblegum, dusty, Belgian yeast, ripe fruit, sweet malt, and light spices in the aroma. Taste is more bubblegum, candied fruit, grains, Belgian yeast, floral hops, light spices and citrus notes. Light tropical fruit as well. Body is light-medium and rather bubbly due to the strong carbonation. Ends with more bubblegum, candi sugar, dried fruit, dusty yeast, floral hops, citrus notes and sweet malts. Nice!

750 ml corked and caged bottle, bottled on 1/19/2010, best before January 2011.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a hazy golden/orange color with a frothy inch and a half white head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is citrus (tropical fruit, grapefruit, orange peel), yeast, pine hops and a bit of cloves.  I think the taste is pretty similar to the aroma, but with the addition of some candi sugar and peppery spice.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating and is well carbonated.  Drinkability is pretty good, its smooth, refreshing and very easy to drink.  Its a good beer today, and would be even better on a hot day.  And for $6.99 a bomber, its a good beer at a good price.

Enjoyed on tap in a chalice.  The beer pours medium amber color, mimicking both the hues of classic American and Belgian pale ales.  The nose is a melange of earthy/grapefruity hops, and Abbey yeast esters.  The flavor picks up where the nose began, and delivers perhaps the best overall mix of American and Belgian flavor available in the U.S.  The beer mimicks la Chouffes beautiful earthy hop flavor, as well as a dry and almost tart finish that allows the beer to be at once complex and deep whilst remaining quite refreshing.  Overall, a superbly brewed and formulated example.

Pours a cloudy golden amber, with a touch of orange. The head is only slightly off white, thick and very long lasting.

 The nose is citrus bubble gum with a floral undertone. The  watery feel and lively carbonation pushes the initial burst of flavor through quickly.  The florals mix with a nicely balanced sweetness. The finish is very metallic and a touch overwhelming, but fades quickly.

 Nice refreshing beer for a summer BBQ. Might also mix well with a spicy thai dish.

25.4 oz bottle.  Misted rusty yellow with a fluffy white head.  Nose is dough, citrus and grass.  Medium light with foamy carb.  Taste is lemon pith and peel with a spritz of lime.  Yeasty with hints of banana.  Dry minerally finish.

750. ml bottle. Pours a thick, tiny bubbled, white head, with attractive lacing, over a clear golden (SRM 5) body.....nose is light citrus, grass, bit of pine, tiny bit of bubblegum and barnyard......taste initially is light biscuit, with sweet malt, then apple, pineapple finishing with a pine bitterness....mouth feel is light to medium, carbonation medium to high. This does not really fit very well into any of the myriad of Belgian styles. The malt back bone is a little light, the hops are more pronounced than usual, and the alcohol level is off for a Golden Strong, and it is much too strong, and hop heavy for a Belgian Pale Ale.  It is a pleasant beer, and I enjoyed it thoroughly. BJCP 7/3/15/4/7

hazy yellow with huge white head.  high carbonation.  light estery nose with some hops.  some bitterness with fruity esters and a light hop crispness and a bone dry finish.  great subtle and restrained flavor.  very nice

16 oz draft. Pours a slightly hazy golden with a small white frothy head. Aroma is very citric, spicy hops, nice fresh fruit characteristics, the cascade hops really jump out, nice bready malt backbone. Flavor starts out sweet, freshly picked citric fruits, picks up and interesting sort of clove spiciness. Almost gains a hybrid hefeweizen american pale ale hybrid taste. Very interesting, Nice lightly bitter hoppy finish, Medium body and a prickly carbonation. Very refreshing and tasty pale ale.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Fruity apricot like aroma with some spicy beligian notes. The flavor has fruity belgian yeast, apricot, and floral hops. Really good.

Tap, City Beer Store.  Good enough but kinda boring.  Bright light brown to gold, just a bit cloudy.  Nice white head. Fairly subdued.  Mostly Belgian yeast, light grain and mild citric hops. Some fruitiness and spice. The yeast is fairly earthy and it probably would have more complexity in a bigger beer, but it seems sort of restrained here. Well-balanced but no real hook.  This beer just isnt quite up to better versions from Belgium.  Good, clean feel.  Very light hop bite. Quite drinkable.  Again, I just would have preferred a bit more to make me want a second glass.  Somewhat forgettable, ultimately.  I dont mean to be harsh - theres very little to criticize specifically about the beer, really. It just didnt hook me in.

draft @ OTH.
Pours golden, thick white head.
Aroma, nice citrus, yeasty, mild tropical nose.
Flavors, bitter hops, pale malts, Belgian yeast, touch of roasted malts, grassy hops and possibly hint of malt sweetness that blends perfectly with the Belgian yeast. This is one tasty pale ale, one that I wish more Belgian breweries could brew as savory as the one Ommegang did.

Pint served at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. with a slightly hazed orange/golden color, silky, white foam to the head, and lasting, curtainy lacing. The aroma was a pleasant blend of citrus, mid-fruit, and floral notes. Added to the mix was some smooth, biscuity malt and light sweetness. The flavor continued the aroma notes, adding moderate bitterness/dryness, and a little spice to the medium body. A very flavorful brew!

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy light orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of light citrus hops, light fruits, orange peel, Belgian yeast, and bready malts.  Flavor of sweet fruits and Belgian yeast with some citrusy hops in the finish.  Not overly hopped but rather the hops blend well with the base beer.  Quite enjoyable!
8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]

On tap, downstairs at the Thirsty Monk. Cloudy orange, nice fluffy white. Very spicy aroma. Surprisingly clean palate. Nice and tasty - some yeasty notes, some bubblegum. As it warms, some notes of rosemary emerge. Very nice stuff.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy honey gold with a moderate, somewhat fluffy, linen white head that lasted until mid-glass and left considerable lace.  Pleasant aroma of orange and  Belgian yeast.  The flavor is malt along with a very solid dose of spicy Belgian yeast.  There is a slight mustiness to the flavor as well.  Dries out towards the finish.  Solid beer.

Lively pour - turbid golden body, with a well-sustained, soapy head - aroma of dry, crackery malts, citrus fruits, banana and other more mild phenols, a hint of wheat and toasted grains - carbonation is a little abrasive at first , but as the beer settles in the glass, it becomes much more soft in the mouth, despite how full it is - taste is semi-dry - a light, tropical fruit sweetness quickly makes way for some dry, biscuity malts, spicy/peppery character, fairly strong hop bitterness (for the style), mild belgian phenolic character (some plastic-like quality way in the back) - despite how dry it is, it is lacking a sturdy crispness that you would want in this style - instead, it is a bit "wet," with a body that kind of falls apart by the finish - still, it is decent, but I am sticking with Hennepin - its better, and quite a bit cheaper.

really nice version of a belgian pale ale. citrus zest, coriandor, like a belgian, perfect coloring and massive white head that stayed forever. very refreshing and perfect abv, not too high that i had to nurse it, not too little that it wasnt present, great beer from a very good brewery
Bottle. Pours golden with a big white head. Flavor is light dry hopping, sugar, yeast, and booze. Solid belgian ale.

750ml shared with tastybeer. Pours a cloudy yellow with a relatively thin white head that leaves very nice lace. Aroma is very yeasty: musty, old closet, esters, some candi sugar. Loads of spice. Taste is dry, slight booziness and candi sugar coming through but mainly doughy malt, dryness. Not too much dry hoppiness coming through. Very good still.

Draft @ Coles in Buffalo NY> Pours a slightly cloudy golden orange (Houblon Chouffe). Nice lacing. Aroma is tangerine, citrus, belgian yeastwith mild hop presence. Taste is dry, sweet malts, citrus hops. Pretty balanced & quite drinkable. Good beer

750ml from Sams, Durham. Always nice to see a new brew from Ommegang. And the brew doesnt fall short of the mark anywhere. But while I appreciate its look (an appealing cloudy pale gold, with roiling carbonation and a fluffy, long-lasting head), its aroma (vague yeast and bright hops, with a touch of bread like a biere de garde and a dry musty saison-like frame), and the taste (gently fruity, with a ripeness or gamey bit in the center), nothing about it knocks me out or even seems altogether too distinctive. Was a bit surprised, but could have been the wrong circumstances or something? Possible rerate for sure.

bottle from chevy chase.  limited edition, and it looks like a blackthorn cider bottle so my eyes missed it the first few times i looked.  pours orangey with a tan head.  nose is sweet with candi sugar and a light syrupy hoppy vibe.  taste is sweet light and very quaffable.  this is very good and very drinkable

750ml bottle. pours a murky golden-amber with foamy white head. aroma has nice hoppy notes that are floral, herbal, and peach. the malt brings a semi sweet stiff biscuity flavor while the hops are spicy, mint, and tangerine. dry finish. a very sold belgian single that i only wish could be sold for at their lower end price point.

Bottle RBWG 10 Pours cloudy yellow with a small, creamy, white head. Excellent retention. Spicy, fruity, citrusy-hop nose. Light to medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. The flavor is a little spicy, fairly hoppy and crisp. Lightly bitter finish. Bottle courtesy of growler!

750ml bottle.  super pop cork rigged.  clear gold with lots of bubbles under a very large foamy white head.  floral and musty hop aroma that is far from bitter or citrus.  the flavor is yeasty with soft tropical and floral hops.  soft to moderate carbonation paves the way for a creamy palate.  grassy, harvested cereal grain finish.  solid.

aroma is pineapple, coconut, beach, ocean, suntan lotion, salty rocky yeast.  appearance is ultra hazy golden sunshine.  flavor is big dry yeast and more soft peach and pineapple bomb hop note devoid of harsh pine or acidic elements. mathematical formulas could not possibly contrive a better ABV for this already sessionable beer.  a simple wonder, even for ommegang whose roster is already filled with beers of this nature.

Orange amber pour with fluffy white head that clings to the glass.  Big tropical fruit aroma with some esters, banana, bubble gum.  Really excellent flavor. Fruity flavor balanced by leafy hops.  Fairly sweet upfront and settling into a dry, light bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium with a slightly creamy texture and good soft carbonation.  Finishes dry.  Absolutely great beer from Ommegang.

750 ml. bottle from Macs on West Peachtree. Wow, I am extremely intoxicated, but I will rate this beer anyways. Copper colored beer. Dark orange haze color, with a fluffy head that fades away quite slowly. Looks like a damn good Belgian ale to me. Bubblegum Belgian yeast aroma poking through with a subtle but refreshing hop aroma. Yeast and sugar are the dominating aromas. Aroma is pungent and aromatic, but you have to realize that this aroma is very sweet smelling. I am not really getting much of a hop aroma. When I taste this beer, I would have to say it is damn near perfect. Belgian yeast and sugar are present, at first. Then I get that lingering citrus bitterness that mixes almost perfectly with the sweet sugar and Belgian yeast flavor(s). The bitterness is not caustic or incisive, but it develops quite well to where it is not intrusive, but complimentary. Banana aroma coming through more, in terms of aroma, as the beer warms. Fresh hop flavor at first, and the a somewhat creamy, but amply carbonated texture provide the perfect taste. A damn fine offering from an unpretentious brewery. This beer is extremely subtle, and yet it provides the right flavors at the right time. A bit too carbonated. Also, if the hop profile was pushed up a bit, this would be perfect. Buy this fresh, or buyer beware; caveat emptor.

Tallahassee, Fl - Market Square Liquors - 750 ml corked bottle. Pours a dark murky orange with a soft white silky head that leaves a nice coat of lacing. Aroma has some nice lemony accents, some spicy notes - saffron comes to mind, and a hint of yeast. Flavor is very refreshing with some soft buttery notes, tart lemon, some cloves and a hint of white grapes. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy. Excellent.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a hazy dark orange with large fluffy head. Aroma of light lemon, some farmhouse, nice hoppy bouquet. Flavor is very balanced, nice farmhouse, light citrus, light grain, nice light grapefruit/pine hoppy notes, earthy with a nice bitterness in the end. Mouth feel is light-medium body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, it is a well put together beer and refreshing on a nice spring day.

bottle, thanks to Stephen for getting this, clear golden orange color with very dense white foam, aroma is thin fruit and sugar, a little hoppy,  flavors of freeze dried pitted fruits, mineral, copper, finish is bright and thin

BCTC 09.  Pours a light hazy gold with a big white head.  Aroma is grassy herbal hops , subdued not harsh spicy yeasty phenolics, light fruitiness- pears and pineapple tropical notes.  Flavor is herbal and doughy malts, light cracker, more spice, phenolics, and light fruit, grassy lightly bitter finish- fairly clean overall and easy drinking.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 (4/18/10, 75cl bottle)  Large and rocky off-white head atop murky amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, spicy/lemon/grass, yeast, light biscuit.  Taste is spicy/grassy, some lemon, yeast, biscuit, light clove.  Fairly dry finish.  Effervescent medium body, light acidity.  (7/3/7/4/14)

(BCTC09, draft) Small white head atop cloudy apple cider body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, clove, banana, some spicy/hoppy.  Taste is medium sweet, spicy yeast, orange/spice.  Light-medium body, some dryness. (/3/7/4/14)

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 BCTC.  Golden with head.  Yeasty sweet marshmallow lemon aroma.  Sweet peach vanilla with mild hop cleanish finish.  A little light and sweet.  Ok.   Re-rate from bottle 7/22/10.  Nicer texture.  Not as sweet.  Nicer spicy yeasty taste and aroma.  Better hoppy spicy dry finish.  Very good.

Draft, BCTC 2009. Pours orange-yellow with a bit of haze, capped with a small off-white head. Crisp floral hop aroma is nicely complimented by caramel and toffee. Flavor is a little on the sweeter side, with toffee and perhaps some candi sugar nicely woven with floral hops and earthy notes. Finishes a bit sweet. Very drinkable.

Tap at BCTC. Lightly cloudy yellow color, minimal head. Light Belgian hoppy funk. Nice, dry light boddy, with a crispy and lemony hop backing things up. Pineapple characteristics remind me slightly of batch 1 Cuvee de Castleton, though there is little int he way of sour here. Solid effort, hope to see this one again where I can drink a bit more of it.

[BCTC 09] Hazy golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus fruits, toffee malts, vanilla, light floral hops, spices, and toast.  Taste of citrus fruits, vanilla, toffee malts, some hay, and a spicy finish.
